PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Colston (from 267 citizens), Harradine (from 91 citizens), Jones (from 203 citizens) and Sheil (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give the required 12 months notice (on or after October 19, 1986) to the United States Government to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the Base closed.
Pine Gap is a nuclear target-it is a danger to Australia's security;
Pine Gap is a ground control station for US Signals Intelligence;
Pine Gap is virtually a US colony in the middle of Australia;
Pine Gap spies on Australian and overseas telephone and telex communications-last year Pine Gap was caught spying on Greece;

Pine Gap is heavily staffed by the US Central Intelligence Agency because it is the single most important US facility in Australia and one of the most important US satellite ground stations in the world;
Pine Gap is situated on Aboriginal land, specifically a sacred dreaming tract;
Pine Gap is an obstacle to the achievement of a nuclear-free and independent Pacific;
Pine Gap helps the US select nuclear targets in the Soviet Union and other countries and as such involves Australia in US nuclear war plans.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Does the Minister agree that current developments on world stock markets combined with last week's poor balance of payments result highlight the riskiness of the Government's Budget and economic strategy of gradual adjustment? Does he agree there is now a clear need for remedial action to increase the pace of economic adjustment, including reconsideration of the Government's submission to tomorrow's wage case hearing and a mini-Budget before the Parliament rises in December?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I agree with a list of propositions. So far as I can remember them, I certainly do not agree with any of them because, of course, they are patently stupid. In regard to the fall this morning in the all ordinaries index in Australia, which was of the same order as yesterday's fall on Wall Street, it should be noted, firstly, that the all ordinaries index is following that fall at the level it was late last year. In other words, there has been a stock market boom in the United States, in Australia and in the industrialised world in general. These things happen from time to time. I have in front of me an extract from Lester Thurow's Zero Sum Solution. With reference to the South Sea bubble which burst in 1720, he wrote:

ANSWER.PARA: A few months before the peak, what may have been the world's smartest man, Sir Isaac Newton, sold his shares for a 7,000 pound profit, with the statement that he could-
this is a quotation from Newton-

`calculate the motions of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people.' Even the world's smartest man, however, could not resist the temptation of rapidly rising prices. He later re-entered the market for shares and eventually lost 20,000 pounds when the stock eventually crashed, wiping everyone out.

Earlier on the same page he referred to the tulip bulb boom of the seventeenth century. These things happen from time to time. I think it has been fairly predictable for several months, if not longer, that a significant decline in share market prices was going to happen sooner or later. And it has now happened. Although the Australian share market would not be tied in a one to one ratio with any other share market, it is not going to remain unaffected by a fall of the magnitude that has been experienced in Wall Street in the last week or so and yesterday in particular. The only ways in which a decline in share prices could have a significant adverse affect on the Australian economy would be if it were to induce a fall in export prices or a significant withdrawal of overseas capital from Australia.

If either of those things were to happen-and there is no evidence or even reason to believe at this stage that they will-my last comment to Senator Chaney is that it is just as well John Howard is not still the Treasurer and it is just as well the country is not in the mess it was when John Howard was the Treasurer, when we were facing a prospective Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion. It is just as well that that sort of fiscal irresponsibility which was displayed by John Howard during his period as Treasurer, and in particular in his last Budget, has been purged from the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I notice that the Minister ignored the reference to last week's balance of payments figures. I ask him to tell the Senate whether he is currently of the view that we are moving in the adjustment processes as quickly as the externally imposed circumstances demand, to use his words.

—The last part of that supplementary question is a matter for judgment. At the margin, there are legitimate reasons for people to come to slightly different judgments. Of course, what is not a question of judgment or opinion is that this Government's policy is moving Australia in the right direction, unlike the policy of the former Government and, in particular, the last Budget brought down by the discredited former Treasurer, which had no economic strategy at all but just a string of irresponsible political bribes, the cost of which was substantially deferred into the next Budget and, therefore, inherited by this Government and the macroeconomic effect of which, of course, was to leave a prospective Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion, a factor which Senator Stone, to his credit, very promptly drew to the notice of the new Government on 6 March 1983. It is a pity that Senator Stone, as a politician, does not continue to display the sort of fiscal responsiblity which he displayed as a Secretary to the Treasury.
—The leopard has changed his spots.

—Yes, the leopard has changed his spots. He now gets around as the mouthpiece for supply side voodoo economics. Even Mr Peacock walked away from that, but not Senator Stone. This former astringent Treasury Secretary is now the mouthpiece for voodoo economics in Australia.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Clearly, the Minister, in his usual manner, is now debating the question. He still has not addressed the question in regard to our balance of payments. I ask you to call him to order.
—The Minister is debating the question.
—Mr President, I have finished now.

— My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. Last week the Housing Industry Association issued a public statement stating that home ownership for the average wage earner was more affordable now than it had been 12 months ago. Can the Minister confirm the accuracy of this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am very pleased to be able to confirm the accuracy of that report from the Housing Industry Association. I presume that all honourable senators will be equally pleased. This Government has introduced a number of initiatives which have improved the affordability of home ownership, particularly for low and moderate income earners. The decision on 2 April 1986 to remove the interest rate ceiling on new savings bank home loans led to a significant improvement in both the availability and the affordability of housing finance. Savings bank home lending increased from $4 billion, in annual terms, in the March quarter 1986 to in excess of $9 billion in March 1987. The total value of home lending in August 1987 was the highest on record, at almost $1.3 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: Prior to April 1986 lending was strictly rationed and some borrowers were required to top up their first mortgage loan with more expensive loans such as personal loans. Following the partial deregulation, borrowers could obtain a single loan, often at a lower cost than the former cocktail loans. The average value of home loans in August 1987 reached a record of $50,000, reflecting improved affordability of housing finance. The changes to the first home owners scheme announced on 30 March this year were designed particularly to help low and moderate income families experiencing difficulty affording a home of their own. The changes will mean that 13,000 households which previously could not have been eligible for assistance will now receive assistance. A further 13,000 households will now receive increased assistance.

Following the Budget, the nationally-operated savings banks announced a cut in housing loan interest rates to 14.5 per cent. The rates on housing loans charged by many permanent building societies have also fallen. Affordability has also been aided by subdued house prices in recent years. In the 12 months ending in June 1987, only Sydney house prices increased in real terms. The combination of lower interest rates, more freely available housing finance, increased eligibility for the first home owners scheme and stable house prices has led to a significant improvement in affordability in the last 12 months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether he recalls telling Labor lawyers in Perth last month, in answer to a question about why the Government had not had an inquiry into wealth:

QUESTION.PARA: Some interesting things might come out of it but you don't have to run a $6 million inquiry to know that having an inheritance tax would be a much more equitable distribution of wealth, albeit over time.

Is he aware that his Centre Left colleagues, Messrs Hayden and Dawkins, have supported the idea of such an inquiry and that the Prime Minister says he will keep an open mind? Does the Minister hold to his view that an inquiry would be an expensive waste of time? Does he agree with Mr Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who said yesterday, `I'd rather have the tax than an inquiry'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I recall saying something a month or so ago, I think it was. I recall saying something like that. I do not think that is completely accurate, but I do not dispute the substance of it. There was no written text of what I said, so I cannot be certain of that. I was also asked a few other silly add-ons to that primary question. Of course, the Government has already decided. Some time ago it asked the Australian Bureau of Statistics to examine existing data on income and wealth to see what scope there is for any improvement or changes. That report has recently been completed and will be looked at by the Government shortly, I expect. But as to whether any further inquiry should be made, that entails a judgment about the likely cost of such an inquiry and the likely value of what it might produce.

ANSWER.PARA: Leaving aside the people who seem to object to an inquiry per se, it has long been the case that the National Party of Australia, or the Australian Country Party as it used to be, has made a virtue of ignorance. I do not think any serious student of the Country Party over the last several decades would dispute that the National Party used to be the only party that made a virtue of ignorance. It now appears that the Liberal Party of Australia is joining it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Federal Government previously offered the Queensland Government funds to assist in the cost of educating nurses at colleges of advanced education? If so, for what use have these funds been available and has the Queensland Government availed itself of any of these funds? Is it a fact that, as stated in the Courier-Mail of 19 October, if the Queensland Government does not accept those Federal funds and allow nurses to have a college education, Queensland nurses will be regarded as underqualified in a second-rate health service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that for three years now Commonwealth funds have been available to assist in the cost of the transfer of nurse training from hospital-based nursing, where it has been traditionally, to college-based nursing, where it is the policy of our Government, the nursing movement and the Royal Australian Nursing Federation to develop it. Nearly three years ago we negotiated an agreement with the States whereby we would make a contribution over and above the grants to States for health training that they have always had to assist in this process and the process was to be complete by 1991. All of the States and Territories except Queensland now have college-based nurse training at some stage of development-some States are going faster than others-and are receiving Commonwealth funds. But the Queensland Government decided not to accept the Commonwealth assistance for this new education development. I think it is an affront to Queensland nurses that the Queensland Government has made this decision. I think it is a setback for the profession in Queensland and, to some extent, nationally, because nurses like to move around between the States, that college-based training is now possible in every State and Territory in Australia apart from Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland Government has tried to claim during the period that we have attempted to negotiate this matter with it, that the Commonwealth should meet the full cost of the college-based training and that there are no savings to be made in the health sector. Of course, this claim by Queensland simply indicates the historically low level of money spent by that State on nurse education. Indeed, every other State currently provides far more hours of curriculum education for nurses in hospital-based courses than does Queensland. In Queensland the general nursing hospital-based course currently involves only 1,200 hours of curriculum education over three years, which compares badly with the 1,600 and 1,800 hours of curriculum in the other States. So it is clear that, even in the case of hospital-trained nurses, Queensland nurses are already at a disadvantage compared with nurses being trained in hospitals in other States and Territories. Added to that disadvantage is the fact that the Queensland Government will not move to take Commonwealth assistance and make college-based training available to Queensland nurses. That amounts to a very sorry picture for the nursing profession in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister say whether cuts are being planned in the staffing levels and functions of the Women's Bureau in the Department of Employment, Education and Training? If such cuts are being planned, will the Minister give details and explain the reasons for them in the context of the Government's repeatedly stated commitment to equal employment opportunities for women?

—It is certainly the case that there is no reduction in the Government's intention to do everything possible to provide equal employment opportunities for women. The role played by the Women's Bureau in recent years has been very important in assisting with labour market analysis, skills needs analysis, and so on. The Women's Bureau will continue to perform that very valuable function and will continue to be part of the network of policies, structures and legislation which are all designed to achieve equal employment opportunity for women. I think it is the case that the Women's Bureau, like all parts of the public sector, will be streamlined to some extent. As to the details of any reductions that are planned for the Women's Bureau, I will take that matter to Mr Dawkins and get a detailed reply for Senator Haines.

—My question is directed to the Minister assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware of the call by the Real Estate Institute of Australia for a rental crisis conference? Does the Minister agree with comments made by the shadow Minister for Community Services that housing costs are too high? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the ways in which the Government has acted to assist low income private renters? Can the Minister advise us of the prospects now faced by first home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not agree with the Opposition spokesperson's comments. Any reference to the record would indicate that our Government has done more to wipe out housing-related poverty than any previous Liberal- National Party government. We have acted on two fronts to assist low income private renters. On the supply side, we have restored negative gearing, which will provide a much needed boost to the private rental sector, particularly in Sydney.
—Why did you take it away?
—The bottom of the barrel.

—I can only report to those opposite who are making sceptical sounds that at the meeting of the Australian Housing Council, which I chaired last week, industry representatives were unanimous in their welcoming of the restoration of negative gearing and in their prediction--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I know it is very difficult for the Opposition to face up to the success of our Government's housing policies-be it in the statistics of home ownership, which I was able to give the Senate earlier today, or in the great improvements we have seen in assistance to low income renters. It is not only the view of the industry but also my view, and that of all housing Ministers who have paid careful attention to this, that the reintroduction of negative gearing will bring private investors back into the rental market, and that will have an effect on the lower end of the market. At the same time assistance to low income family renters of $15 a week was announced in the Budget this year as a part of the family package; that is $15 a week additional to the $22 or $28 per child. I think everyone concerned about housing-related poverty and family poverty has welcomed that package as the greatest step forward in defeating poverty, including housing-related poverty, that we have seen.

ANSWER.PARA: As well as that, under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, our Government is committed to providing $700m this year and for the two subsequent years. Legislation to that effect will be coming into the Senate shortly. So it is quite clear that, for the people at the lower end of the market, the private renters, although they still face economic and supply difficulties, the Government has taken a number of significant steps which have never previously been taken by a government. This has certainly ameliorated the circumstances for many low income private renters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the document from which she quoted.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—No, it is confidential.

—My question is also to Senator Ryan and follows the answer she has just given. I thank her for her very good explanation of why negative gearing is of value. I ask: Why did her Government abolish negative gearing and cause the problems in the housing area and the rest of the construction industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to have a demarcation dispute with my colleague Senator Walsh, but I will point out to Senator Chaney that at the time the negative gearing provision was withdrawn there was no capital gains tax. So the investor in the private rental market was getting a double whammy.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the facts are very distressing to senators opposite because they are so favourable to the Government. It was quite clear that at the time of the first major package of tax reforms, investors in the private rental market not only could get the significant benefits of negative gearing but also could then sell their property and not pay any tax on the profits made. That is no longer the case.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite are very tedious, Mr President. It is now the case that negative gearing has been restored and investors who invest in the private rental market, sell their properties and make a capital gain, will pay tax on that, so equity has been restored.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I ask the Minister whether he has seen reports that much of Australia's film heritage, including films such as Raymond Langford's silent masterpiece On Our Selection, and The Cheater made by our first female production team, is in danger of disintegrating? Is it a fact that the National Film and Sound Archive has 10 million feet of uncopied nitrate film which is in danger of disintegrating? Further, is it a fact that the Archive needs another $1.5m a year for the next 12 years to preserve all its nitrate films? Can the Minister indicate what the Government has done and what options are open to it in the future to preserve these films?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the Press reports, in particular, the one in the October issue of Australian Society. I am happy to assure honourable senators that acetate preservation copies of Raymond Langford's On Our Selection, and The Cheater made by the McDonaghs, our first female production team, were made some time ago. So while the article may have got that wrong, I would also have to concede that the National Film and Sound Archive does indeed have some 10 million feet of uncopied nitrate film which is in danger of disintegrating. It is also true that preservation of these films would cost something like $1 1/2m a year for 12 years. In times of economic restraint, the National Film and Sound Archive fared comparatively well with other collecting institutions in this Budget. But, with finite resources, the National Film and Sound Archive is giving urgent priority to the preservation of Australian film. It is assigning a heritage rating to endangered footage to ensure that the most significant films are preserved.

ANSWER.PARA: I am conscious of the problem of the disintegration of the film footage held by the National Film and Sound Archive and because of that I have had some discussions with its officials. The Archive is seeking additional funds from private sponsors. It should be noted that its sister body in the United Kingdom recently got a $60m grant from the Getty Foundation. While I cannot promise to be of assistance in getting a $60m grant, I shall do what I can with private sponsorship to see whether I can be of some assistance in its endeavours.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In response to an earlier question from Senator Chaney, the Minister said, when describing the stock market crash overnight, that `these things happen from time to time'. Would the Minister care to expand his historical lecture to the Senate by telling us what happened to the British economy after the bursting of the South Sea bubble, and what happened to the Dutch economy after the bursting of the tulip boom? More seriously, because these are serious matters, in the light of developments overnight in major stock markets overseas and further such developments in the Japanese stock market this morning, does the Minister accept that these developments are likely to affect adversely the previously forecast outlook for the economies concerned? If so, what consequences does the Minister foresee for the forecasts about the international economic environment, on the basis of which our own recent Budget for 1987-88 was framed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone could not have been paying attention to my answer to the first question. I think that he would agree that the two ways in which a major decline in share prices throughout the world could adversely affect the Australian economy would be if they induced either a fall in the price of our exports or a significant withdrawal of capital from Australia. There is no evidence, to my knowledge anyway, that either of those things is likely to happen. Whether they happen is something that only time will tell.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to what happened to the British economy after the South Sea bubble burst, there was, I think, a fairly prolonged recession. However, if Senator Stone is suggesting-he may not have been-that precisely the same thing would happen in Australia following the decline in share prices this morning and the smaller decline over the last week or so, he should bear in mind the order of magnitude of the South Sea bubble collapse, plus the fact that governments are more interventionist today than they were in the eighteenth century. Senator Stone would probably like to take us back to the eighteenth century, but I do not think that is likely to happen.

As to what happened to the Dutch economy after the tulip bulb boom burst, I am afraid I do not know; but if anybody would like to know what would have happened to the Australian economy had Mr Howard remained the Treasurer in 1983, I cannot think of any better description of what was likely to have happened than that penned by Senator Stone in his former incarnation as Secretary to the Treasury, and which he would have delivered to Mr Howard on 6 March 1983 had Mr Howard still been Treasurer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I draw the Minister's attention to a recent judgment by Justice K. Murray in the Family Court in South Australia on 6 August 1987. It reads in part:

QUESTION.PARA: It will be clear from these reasons that if the wife has become pregnant and given up work by then, and . . . her new husband is secure in his employment at the Royal Adelaide Hospital the wife should have custody of the two children so long as she remains in the State of South Australia. If any of these conditions are not satisfied, then the husband will have custody of the children.

The case was adjourned on 7 October. The wife was not pregnant by then, so custody went to the husband. Can the Minister say whether this judgment is sufficient to have the judge removed? What assistance or further investigation can or will the Attorney-General undertake in this case? Can the Minister guarantee that no further judgments of this sort will emerge from the Family Court? What steps can be taken to overturn this bizarre custody ruling immediately, pending legal appeal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had some parts of this judgment drawn to my attention in the few minutes before Question Time. I have not had an opportunity to read the full judgment and therefore it would be remiss of me to comment as though I had access to the whole judgment of Justice K. Murray, a female member of the Family Court in South Australia. But it appears from the little of the judgment I have had an opportunity to read that, indeed, the granting of custody to the woman concerned was subject to conditions which were quite extraordinary and even bizarre. As for the idea that the custody of children might be subject to the custodial parent becoming pregnant, I know of no similar case in the common law and I doubt whether any other legal system would countenance such a matter being subject to what is obviously conjugal union beforehand and a successful result of that union. I am unable to say whether this judgment is being considered by authorities other than me or the Attorney-General with a view to having the judge removed. It does not fall within my power either to suggest or to make such a removal.

ANSWER.PARA: I am further asked: What assistance or further investigation can or will the Attorney-General undertake in this case? Given the gravity of the matters raised by Senator Crowley and given their complex nature and their ramifications, I will certainly refer them to my colleague the Attorney-General for a more detailed answer. I cannot give the guarantee that no further judgments of this sort will emerge from the Family Court. However, perhaps the sort of publicity that Senator Crowley's question is now giving to this judgment will give similarly minded justices, if there are any, some pause.

I am finally asked: What steps can be taken to overturn this bizarre custody ruling immediately pending appeal? I have not had time to check, but I believe that it is quite normal practice, and it may have been attempted by the woman concerned in this case, to ask the judge for a stay of the implementation of the judgment pending appeal. That ought to have been undertaken, but I am unable to say whether it was and I am not in the business of giving legal opinions as to whether it ought to be attempted now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has Qantas Airways Ltd engaged consultants on, or is it in any other way looking at options for, the sale of all or part of the airline, as has recently been reported? Does this action have the support of the Minister and the Government? Does the Minister agree that this is prudent forward planning by Qantas in light of the apparently inevitable move by the Government towards at least partial privatisation of the Government's wholly owned domestic and international airlines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas will have a major funding requirement in the near future to enable it to re-equip with new aircraft and to retain competitiveness with other international airlines. The extent of that financial commitment is presently estimated at some $4 billion over the next five years, measured in dollars of the day. The residual capital injection that is presently estimated to be necessary to secure that, bearing in mind the sorts of sums that Qantas may be able to raise by way of internally generated funding and further on the loan market, in very rough figures is $400m, with most of the requirement tending to be concentrated around the year 1989. So it is evident that there is a quite formidable capitalisation problem confronting the corporation.

ANSWER.PARA: As one would expect of any competently managed airline, Qantas is, quite properly and understandably, undertaking its own full study of its requirements for future funds, including an analysis of the appropriate mix of capital, borrowings and internally generated funds. I understand that Qantas has an ongoing consultancy arrangement with merchant bankers to assist it in this issue and that no special consultancy arrangements have been entered into in recent times. Notwithstanding a suggestion in a newspaper report to this effect, the Government has appointed no merchant bank or any other advisers in relation to Qantas's capital problems and has not embarked upon any analysis at this stage of what might be required so far as meeting Qantas's capital needs is concerned. Clearly, however, it is a major issue, one that we will need to look at very closely. As the Prime Minister has foreshadowed, in the context of not only Qantas, but Australian Airlines and a number of other government business enterprises as well, it does demand a careful analysis of the data and the policy issues associated with problems of this kind. I am presently considering how the Government might embark upon such an analysis of its own in the context of Qantas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article appearing on page 44 of the 9 October 1987 issue of the Business Review Weekly magazine? Does that article expose the myth of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's claim that Queensland is a low tax State? How do Queensland's hidden taxes affect Australia's national economic performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last part of the question, there are always some difficulties or hazards in ascribing a particular outcome to a particular cause. But it is a matter of record that the performance of the Queensland economy, relative to the rest of Australia, particularly over the last four years, has been abysmal. On almost every index of economic activity or economic health one finds that Queensland is either the most unhealthy or the second most unhealthy of all the States. The article published in the 9 October issue of the Business Review Weekly explains the range of hidden taxes that are imposed on Queensland by the Bjelke-Petersen Government, the most important of which, of course, is the hidden tax of high railway freight charges for the transport of coal in particular from mines to ports. There is one particular paragraph in the article that I believe is worth quoting:

ANSWER.PARA: Coal rail freight profit shave enabled the Premier . . . to hold back on tobacco and fuel tax, financial institution taxes and death duties. If these taxes and duties had been applied on the same basis as in other states, they would have raised up to $400 million a year. Coal rail freight profits are tied to tonnage, not to price. This means the Government has received profits from the industry while mining companies have faced low prices and losses.

The coal mining companies which pay these hidden taxes have, quite legitimately in my view, been complaining for some time about the severity of them and have cause to complain more loudly now since the price of coal is being squeezed by a world oversupply. An attempt was made by the Utah Development Co. Ltd some 18 months ago, or thereabouts, to quantify the effects of these hidden taxes, excessive rail freights, on the mining industry in Queensland. If I remember correctly, the figure that Utah came up with as the hidden tax component of the railway freight charge was of the order of $350m. Obviously, a hidden tax of that magnitude, which is not related in any way to the price of coal but simply to the tonnage which is being carried, must do a good deal of damage to the mining industry and, in particular, it is likely to do a good deal of damage at a time when coal prices are depressed because of world oversupply.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Government believe that there should be trade or other economic sanctions directed against the regime in Fiji? If not, what is the Government doing to have existing union shipping bans lifted and to prevent the threatened imposition today on air travel to Fiji? Does the Minister expect that the Government will prove as impotent in this instance as it was after the first coup when similar bans seriously jeopardised important markets for Australia's primary products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made it clear all along that we do not support the imposition of trade or economic sanctions against the military regime in Fiji, notwithstanding our obvious position in relation to that regime-our non-recognition of it and our appreciation of the concerns and indeed our sharing of the concerns of the trade union movement about the treatment of unionists in Fiji. It needs to be appreciated that the particular bans that are being imposed at a maritime level and being talked about in an aviation context are not an attempt to bring down the regime as such or even to impose political pressure on it; rather, they are a response to the situation which is a very unhappy one so far as the treatment of fraternal trade union organisations and individual trade unionists is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: Notwithstanding all of that, the Government's position is one of a belief that such sanctions are likely to be counterproductive and, certainly in the Fijian context, are not likely to be effective given the ready availability of other sources of supply for the commodities that are involved and the lack of any evident regional or, for that matter, larger international will to join in any sanctions exercise. So against that background we are continuing to talk with the trade union movement to make it see the force of the argument that we are putting about the likely lack of utility of any such sanctions exercise. We hope that in due course, and sooner rather than later, that approach by the Government, which is, realistically, the only approach we can adopt at this stage, will bear fruit.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING: PROPOSED RESTRUCTURING

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of widespread concern in the community about the possible effects of the proposed restructuring of the advisory bodies and administration of the Department of Employment, Education and Training? What consultations took place with teachers, parents and students in the development of this proposal? What opportunities will be available for these and other groups to influence the final shape of the restructure?

—The proposed restructuring of advisory bodies within the new portfolio of Employment, Education and Training was announced by Mr Dawkins on 15 October. Mr Dawkins advises that the proposed structure was developed from the work of a task force headed by Mr Charles Halton, which included some initial contact by him with key organisations, unions and education providers. The proposals have attracted a wide measure of public support since their announcement. However, Mr Dawkins is aware that some concern has been expressed, chiefly by interest groups uncertain of the retention of their position and access in the proposed structure. It is to resolve such concerns and to clarify relationships that the structure is at this stage only a proposal, subject to consultations. Mr Dawkins advises that these consultations will take place over the next two or three weeks and those organisations which wish to do so will be able to put their views on the proposal to the Halton task force.

—I refer to an article in yesterday's Sydney Daily Mirror and direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Will the Minister confirm that the article quoting Mr John Bowdler, Deputy Secretary of the Department, which said that the Priority One: Young Australia scheme, launched by the Prime Minister in 1985, has been dumped, is correct? If it is correct, in light of the earlier defence of Priority One when this matter has been raised in the Senate, will the Minister explain why Priority One has been abandoned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not read the Daily Mirror yesterday afternoon so I do not know whether the quote as stated by Senator Walters is as she described it. I remind the Senate that there were a number of elements in Priority One. It was a strategy to improve opportunities for youth, particularly those young people who were dropping out of school before year 12 and who had no access to education and training. Statistics clearly show that great advances have been made with regard to the various parts of the Priority One strategy. Even Senator Walters must be aware of the dramatic success in improving retention rates of students towards the end of year 12, which have increased from one- third to a half during the period of the Hawke Administration, and they are up again this year. So that part of Priority One has certainly not been dumped and it will be accelerated and improved under the newly strengthened education and training policies.

ANSWER.PARA: The other major aspect of Priority One was the youth traineeships. Perhaps even Senator Walters will recall that the traineeships were aimed at providing a formal training opportunity for young people for whom there was no other appropriate education or training possibility. As I am sure everyone in the Senate knows, the development of the traineeships was slower than the Government anticipated when this scheme was announced; however, I am pleased to report that there have been some dramatic improvements in the development of traineeships just recently. Mr Dawkins will announce, or will have announced, our expectation that the numbers of traineeships available for young people this year and next year will increase very rapidly now that more co-operation with the trade union movement and with employers who will provide the training has been achieved. Both the policies of achieving increased participation in year 12 and achieving new and better opportunities for training for teenagers are still very much in place and are being pursued very successfully.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I again ask the Minister: Has Priority One been dumped and have the figures of those employed that the Prime Minister assured us would be reached any chance of being reached?

—I thought I had just explained to Senator Walters the two major elements that constituted the Priority One campaign. The first was increased participation of students, particularly disadvantaged students, towards year 12. That strategy is succeeding and we expect the numbers to improve even further this year and in subsequent years. Although the traineeship program developed more slowly than was anticipated when it was announced, we certainly expect a rapid increase in the number of traineeships available. So both major elements of Priority One are in place and on target.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to a report in last Saturday's Brisbane Courier-Mail that, according to Queensland National Party President, Sir Robert Sparkes, a 25 per cent flat rate tax remains a `vitally important blue-print for taxation and related reform'? Will the Government accept Sir Robert's advice and examine the 25 per cent flat tax proposal in the course of its review of corporate taxation?

—I think I can confidently assert that the Government will not be accepting advice from Sir Robert Sparkes. It does not surprise me and I do not think it would surprise many other people that Sir Robert Sparkes is still committed to voodoo supply side economics with incentivation and all those other things tacked on to it. What is alarming is that somebody who is not by background a Queensland National Party redneck, somebody who used to pride himself on being an intellectual and who was once Secretary to the Treasury, also, according to the weekend news reports, remains committed to the supply side voodoo that is attached to a 25 per cent flat tax. I do not know whether Senator Stone is still committed to the bonus for working proposition which he put up during the election campaign-or rather that the Queensland Premier put up on his behalf, I suppose one could say-which would, of course, provide immense benefits for superannuated departmental secretaries who became politicians and for Australian Capital Territory doctors if they were successful in getting the 69 per cent pay increase that they are attempting to screw out of the taxpayers. However, if ACT doctors were successful in screwing out of the taxpayers the 69 per cent pay increase that they are attempting to get, it would not do much for the rest of the people of Australia. Of course, on the debit side of Senator Stone's cum Bjelke-Petersen's pre-election document, or whatever it was, with the 25 per cent flat tax, the bonus for working and all the rest of that supply side nonsense, we were still left ultimately, after we allowed for the $4.7 billion of specified expenditure cuts, with some $18 billion of unspecified expenditure cuts. Fiscal irresponsibility of that magnitude is not really surprising when it comes from the National Party in Queensland, but I must say that it is very surprising and disappointing when it comes from somebody who was once Secretary to the Treasury.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. I refer to her somewhat surprising response to the Senate earlier this afternoon when she justified the Government's decision on 17 July 1985 to reduce the income tax advantage associated with the negative gearing of rental property investments because there was at the time no capital gains tax. I ask: Is the Minister aware that the capital gains tax was introduced on 19 September 1985? Was not the Government at that time, in July 1985, advocating its intention to introduce in the immediate future a capital gains tax? If negative gearing was not necessary if a capital gains tax was in place, why has the Government taken so long to reverse its decision of 17 July 1985?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the dates in front of me to check what Senator Watson said, but perhaps I could again explain to him clearly the circumstances facing investors in the private rental market and how they have changed in three stages. Prior to the Government's package of tax reform, the investor in the private rental market had available to him or her a negative gearing opportunity plus no capital gains tax. It is true that the Government announced its withdrawal of negative gearing, which changed the situation, and not long after that announced the intention to legislate for a capital gains tax. As my colleague Senator Walsh has pointed out, that process took some time.
—You were aware of it?

—Of course we were aware of it. Having then observed and monitored the effects on the attractions of private rental investment to investors, the Government has decided that, since the capital gains tax is in place and is now gaining revenue because some of those properties have been turned over and capital gains taken from them, it is now time to make investment in the private rental market attract a similar kind of negative gearing advantage to that which investment in other areas attracts.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been three separate situations. There was the situation prior to 1985 when there was negative gearing and no capital gains tax. There was then a period when there was no negative gearing, plus no capital gains tax. Now there is a capital gains tax plus negative gearing. I hope that Senator Watson can understand that. I hope that he will also understand that the decision of the Government now, in a changed capital gains tax environment, to reintroduce the negative gearing provisions will attract, as an investor into the private rental market, the smaller type of investor who can afford perhaps to rent out one flat or one house and who will provide more private rental accommodation at the lower end of the market. It may also affect other parts of the market, but we are particularly interested in the fact that it ought to create more opportunities for the private renter at the lower end of the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Could the Government not have foreseen the consequences of its action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson will remember that the time those decisions were made or foreshadowed was the time of the most dramatic and radical series of tax reforms that any Australian government has engaged in.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Remember the fringe benefits tax, which, of course, was opposed. If Senator Watson is saying that every aspect of the post-reform investment environment could have been foreseen with great precision at that time, I think he is saying something that no sensible person really ought to say. We have monitored closely the effects of the various tax reform measures that we have put in place. Also, many changes have taken place in the housing market. Today I have already given the Senate two lots of statistics--
—Very favourable ones.

—As my colleague Senator Tate is aware, I have given very favourable statistics on the increased affordability of home ownership; on the great increases in the number of people of low income who are now able to buy a home; on the increase in public housing provision, assisted by the Commonwealth's efforts under the Commonwealth-State housing agreements; and on the lower interest rates which, of course, are bringing many more people into the situation of being able to afford their own home. None of these things could have been predicted precisely when we embarked on this course of reform. So we have monitored all of these things. We now believe that the time is right to reintroduce the negative gearing opportunity for those investing in the private rental market, thus putting private rental accommodation on an equal basis with other available investments. But, of course, we know that we will be able to reap the capital gains tax payable when those properties are turned over.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. What action does the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs take to limit the potential for domestic violence in Filipino-Australian marriages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for his question. We recognise, however, that the migration process can cause added strains in a marriage. Migration officers provide as much information as possible about life in Australia at the time of interview and copies of the guide book Living in Australia are given out with every visa.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department recently negotiated a visit to Australia by two counsellors employed in Manila by the Commission for Filipinos Overseas. This counselling service is very important and we hope that it will overcome some of the concerns that have been publicly expressed.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the fact that United States bases on Australian soil, such as Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape, are nuclear targets and add to the potential of war, will his Government now act to remove the bases, especially as the Pine Gap lease expired yesterday and in view of the many demonstrations over the past weekend by Australians against the presence of the bases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position in relation to Pine Gap and the other joint facilities was well spelt out by the Prime Minister in his statement of 6 June 1984, which I urge Senator Jenkins to look at. Our position has not changed in any respect since then. The Australia-United States joint defence research facility at Pine Gap contributes, in our clear view, to the maintenance of an effective deterrent relationship between the super-powers and plays an important role in verifying arms control agreements. The avoidance of nuclear war, therefore, underlies the purposes of the joint facilities. All the functions and activities of those facilities, and Pine Gap in particular, require, and have, the full knowledge and concurrence of the Australian Government. It is not a military base. There are no combat personnel, no combat equipment, no military stores or workshops, no plant, machinery or laboratories for research, development, production or maintenance of any weapons or combat systems of any type.

ANSWER.PARA: The language used by Senator Jenkins is also a misrepresentation of the situation to the extent that she referred, as many do, to a lease which requires renewal or renegotiation. The idea that facilities operate on leases for which some kind of rent could be charged-another common theme of the opponents here-is clearly quite incompatible with the concept of jointness which is enshrined in the relevant agreements and which governs the operations of these facilities. The Pine Gap facility operates under an unclassified government-to-government agreement, the non-terminable period for which expired yesterday, 19 October. Henceforth, that agreement continues in force unless either side gives 12 months notice of termination. I repeat that the Government, for the reasons I have outlined, does not intend to give notice of such termination.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, follows the answer she gave to Senator Walters in which she said that the objectives of the Priority One: Young Australia scheme were to develop traineeships in both the public and private sectors and to increase the participation rate of young people in secondary schools. Is it not a fact that those objectives are designed to better equip youth for employment and that the overall objective of the Priority One scheme is to increase the participation rate of youth in the work force? Is it not a fact that, by reference to that test, namely, the increased participation of youth in the work force, Priority One has failed, and has failed decidedly? Is it not therefore a fact that the whole concept of Priority One should again be reconsidered and that the Government should attend to the type of structural discrimination that is being experienced by youth in employment because of the employment and family policies of successive governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly the case that the longer term objective of giving young people better education and training opportunities is so that they will have better opportunities in the work force. It is also the case that those young people who have increased the length of time they spend in the education system, or who have been fortunate enough to get a traineeship, generally have shown a higher level of success at moving into the labour market than those without those skills. Of course, I acknowledge that there is still a lot to be done in this area and that there are still too many young people leaving school and attempting to join the work force and failing to do so. It is for this reason that we are streamlining and upgrading the way in which we are preparing young people for the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of any structural discrimination against young people entering the work force, but I am aware of their lack of appropriate skills. I point out that we are quite a long way down the track from the time when we first announced Priority One. Certainly, there has been some refining and renegotiation of some aspects of that package. Perhaps the most important thing-I know Senator Harradine has had a long-standing interest in this-is that more traineeships will be coming on-stream both in the public sector, in which I know that Senator Harradine has had an interest, and in the private sector. We expect to make a big dent in the youth unemployment figures by the continued success of increased participation through to year 12 and also by the opening up of more traineeships in both the public and the private sectors.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA: PURCHASE OF EASEMENT RIGHTS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October Senator Alston asked me a question drawn from a report in the Business Review Weekly about Telecom Australia purchasing exclusive easement rights to the Victorian Railways network. I have a detailed answer for him which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The newspaper report referred to by the honourable senator is untrue in that, although Telecom has entered into a long term agreement with Vistel Pty Ltd, a telecommunications network management company formed by the Victorian Government, it has not purchased or been given exclusive rights of access to Victorian Railway network easements.

Telecom has a statutory right to enter all land, including land belonging to the Victorian Railway Authorities, under section 16 of the Telecommunications Act 1975 for the purposes of establishing, operating or maintaining telecommunications facilities. However, the Telecommunications Act says nothing about the attitude which any landowner should adopt towards such entry by Telecom. The agreement between Telecom and Vistel Pty Ltd requires the Victorian authorities to facilitate such access, where it is considered desirable, to provide the Victorian Government with the telecommunications services covered in the agreement.

It is quite open, so far as both the Telecommunications Act and the agreement are concerned, for the Victorian Government to grant access rights to railway easements to other parties for telecommunications or any other purpose it may please.
In answer to the honourable senator's further questions on the matter:
no, the agreement reflects no intention on Telecom's part to secure exclusive access rights nor am I aware of any such intention by Telecom;
no, I do not agree that the agreement in any way pre-empts the current review of telecommunications policy which I announced in September;
no, the agreement will not exclude potential new entrants in telecommunications network service markets, should those markets be opened to competition, for the reasons already referred to.

On the matter of the reported cost savings of $20m per annum, reported in the newspaper article, this figure was attributed by the journalist to the Victorian Government's Task Force. It is not a Telecom estimate nor a matter that I would wish to comment on. The Victorian Government may make savings in many ways, including rationalisation of its own staff numbers and work processes, not necessarily associated with reductions in its telecommunications costs. It also may reasonably compare the method it is pursuing with Telecom with other alternatives for carrying projected traffic volumes. These are matters for the Victorian Government to assess and, if it wishes, to make public. The important point is that Telecom has not offered a discount that would flow on to other customers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, on 9 October, asked me a question about remote telephone connections to which I also now have a reasonably detailed answer. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
SENATOR BOSWELL asked the Minister for Transport and Communications a Question Without Notice on 9 October 1987 regarding `Remote Telephone Connections'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the importance of modern communications to people living and conducting businesses in rural and remote areas. The progress Telecom has made to date in its Rural and Remote Areas Programme (RRAP) is evidence of the importance placed on the provision of these services. Since the commencement of the programme in 1984-85 some 28,000 modernised and new services have been provided throughout rural and remote areas of Australia requiring a capital investment in the order of $235 million. This achievement represents over 60% of the estimated 43,500 services scheduled to be provided under the programme at a total capital cost of approximately $526 million (at 1987-88 prices), as well as additional costs for sales tax and customs duties and substantial ongoing maintenance and operation costs. The number of people now awaiting connection or conversion is approximately 15,500, not 18,000 as mentioned in your question.

Given the enormous scale and cost of the programme and the need for financial responsibility in the present economic climate, the future progress of the programme needs to be considered in terms of the availability of capital funds and Telecom's overall service obligations. Telecom has been required to undertake internal economies and postpone planned projects across many areas of its activities, affecting both country and metropolitan subscribers. Reductions to the RRAP are a small proportion of the overall figure.

Telecom is pressing ahead with the programme (some $100m will be spent in 1987-88) giving preference to larger communities. The programme should be substantially completed by 1990 although on present indications delays of up to two years could occur for some of the more isolated customers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Given the importance of the export trade to Australia, the efficiency of our waterfronts is of primary significance to all Australians. Given the island nature of my State of Tasmania, especially its high export trade, it is particularly important to Tasmania.

The number of committees that have recently reported and are currently investigating the efficiency of our waterfront I think illustrates the importance that is attributed to this area of activity. I will quote from a statement by the then Minister for Transport in May this year when he said:

The challenge on the waterfront is difficult not the least because of existing entrenched attitudes and practices which may have been appropriate to earlier times but are quite inappropriate for today's economic circumstances.

I submit that this Labor Government has taken far too long to act. We have had inquiries and rhetoric, but very little action. Unfortunately, the problem of industrial action on the waterfront is fairly widespread. The Australian Chamber of Shipping announced recently that the number of man hours lost on the waterfront in 1985-86 was 310,000. This compares with a figure of some 122,786 man hours lost in 1982-83. Clearly, we have a very significant problem in this area. In fact, the London Shipowners Association has reported that 54 per cent of claims relating to losses of earnings through strikes were incurred on Australia's waterfront. The next in line was Canada, with only 14 per cent of claims. This is a record that Australia should not be proud of. Australia just cannot afford to lose its credibility in the international marketplace. It must cultivate an image of being a regular supplier. Of course, the waterfront must co-operate in this area and play its part. We simply cannot afford to have our export markets endangered by the threat of trade union action to freeze activity on the waterfront. I think the question has to be asked: Do waterfront workers today have too much power? I think we could be forgiven for believing that they do when we hear today that they are making a decision on whether to ban exports to Fiji. They appear at least to have the power to make decisions on matters of foreign policy.

I also make the point that the level of industrial disputation that occurs at any one port will, unfortunately, have an impact on the future of that port. For example, a Tasmanian group which has been considering the establishment of a new Bass Strait ferry is currently looking at a number of ports to decide where the proposed service could best operate from. A high level of industrial disputation could well discount certain ports from consideration due to their waterside workers and the local community. However, all is not bleak. There are encouraging signs to suggest that negotiations between all the parties concerned can result in co-operation on the waterfront to the benefit of all Australians. I would like to quote an example from my home State of Tasmania, where the Port of Launceston Authority has this year made an agreement with commercial stevedores to form the Bell Bay Cargo Services. This association, which is the first of its kind in Australia, shows that it is possible for government, industry and waterside employees to work together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of Senator Watson's speech was better than the first. There is a tendency unjustly to criticise unions and the Waterside Workers Federation. An example of how it is unjust is the case of the Melbourne section of the Waterside Workers Federation, of which the President is Mr Jim Beggs. Much of the criticism made of the waterside workers' actions was found, on examination, to be wrongly placed. For example, there were allegations that they had ruined a cargo of fruit and it was found that that was wrong in the sense that it was damaged--
—I did not say that.

—I am talking about the general criticism made by Senator Watson of the Waterside Workers Federation at the beginning and middle of his speech, although by the end he had come round the other way and acknowledged that it had contributed mightily in certain areas. I am rebutting the suggestion that Senator Watson made at the start of his speech that the Waterside Workers Federation needed, in some way, to be condemned roundly. I am simply saying that there is another side to that story and an example of that is the Melbourne section of the Waterside Workers Federation, which has gone to farmers and explained the situation. During those discussions, it has found that much of the criticism directed at it should have been directed elsewhere. For example, a cargo of fruit coming from the country was ruined in transit by a transport truck, which had nothing to do with the Waterside Workers Federation, although the damage was blamed on it.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the criticism, the Federation has been to country Victoria and discussed the matters with farmers, and as a result a greater understanding has developed. The relationship between the farmers of Victoria and the waterside workers has improved to the extent where they consult. Much of the criticism is a result of misunderstandings and, at a time when there is a great need for consensus between employers and employees, better relationships can be developed by different bodies-in this case the farmers and the unions-talking about matters together. The initiative was taken by the waterside workers. They visited the farming bodies and, although they met with hostility to start with, when the situation was explained that hostility disappeared. The farmers then came down to the wharves and were warmly received, so the development of a proper relationship has occurred.

There is a tendency to look at situations as they were in the old times. Fortunately, these times have passed and we should look positively at these situations, as Senator Watson did at the end of his speech, although that optimism was not there at the start. There are grounds for optimism, and this example of the Melbourne waterside workers shows how co-operation between different bodies in the community and between employers and employees can develop and go on to produce greater and greater productivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is of considerable significance because it represents part of an attempt to come to grips with the situation on the waterfront, which is of great importance to our trade. I do not wish to speak at length on the report-indeed, the sessional order does not permit me to do so. However, I want to refer the Senate to the progress report to the Inter-State Commission by the Chairman of the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee, Sir John Moore. Sir John Moore's report highlights some of the very significant problems in the Australian labour market, quite apart from but also including the waterfront.
—The waterfront was a problem for Sir John Moore.

—I will not take up that point at this stage. Madam Acting Deputy President, I direct your attention to the fact that a series of discussions promoted by Sir John Moore has involved the work force in discussing practices on the waterfront. We find Sir John Moore reporting that the examination has been approached by all parties in a constructive and positive way, although the attitude of unions varied from port to port. Sir John Moore goes on to say that changes are to be recommended. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The recommended changes will result in manning reductions for particular jobs and afford overall a greater degree of efficiency in stevedoring operations, once the national agreement has been reached.

Those words really struck me, because they typify the difficulty we have in coming to grips with the problem of becoming a competitive country. We seem to have a succession of areas where work practices are discussed but where it is simply not accepted that the greatest efficiency needs to be achieved at the work place without further ado. In this case we have inefficient work practices being disclosed, excessive manning levels and a postponement of any action on those things until we have had some national agreement on the matter. This is rather akin to the approach which was adopted by the Government in doing something about work practices in the heavy engineering field and in the shipbuilding industry, where an extraordinarily bureaucratic approach seems to be taken to doing anything about work practices which are, in fact, strangling this country economically. Our competitor countries simply do not allow themselves the luxury of this sort of delay.

I have been talking to an Australian industry leader who is one of the people appointed by the Government to perform functions within these arrangements-Mr Deveson from the Nissan company. I recall in my last conversation with him his comments about the flexibility of the Japanese work force and the capacity of the Japanese to move very quickly to use their labour and their equipment more effectively. He stressed the difficulty for Australia of competing with that sort of flexibility. In this report we see again evidence of the ossification of the whole way we work in this country, a way which I believe is thoroughly destructive. Whilst I think the intentions in devising a waterfront strategy are correct, I say to the Government that the really correct strategy for Australia is to accept that these practices should be dealt with at the work place and that, when an inefficient work practice is disclosed, it should be done away with. I think, from my limited knowledge on the waterfront, that one cannot blame the work force entirely for the difficulties there, any more than one could blame the work force for the difficulties that existed at Robe River, because historically there had been management acquiescence in practices which seemed sensible at the time but which have proved to be quite absurd and uneconomic and which certainly cut down Australia's competitiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not seem sensible at the time.

—I guess they seemed affordable at the time, and management, for one reason or another, went along with them. So my plea is directed as much to management as it is to the work force. There needs to be an absolute concentration by everybody in the enterprise on producing a more productive result not only for the enterprise but also for Australia. I see this report as a sad commentary upon our way of doing things in Australia. If we continue to take the approach that we have to superimpose an additional bureaucracy every time we want to get a work practice changed, or that we have to grant a wage rise every time we get a work practice changed, this country will never succeed in meeting the challenge it faces. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

That this House consents to termination by the Commonwealth of the Airlines Agreement 1981.
upon which Senator Messner had moved by way of amendment:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was adjourned I had said that the Opposition supported the need to abolish the two-airline agreement. I personally welcome that, having been opposed to the Airlines Agreement Act when it previously went through the Senate. The consequences of the decision to abolish the two-airline agreement inevitably are that Australian Airlines must be sold, whatever the left wing of the Australian Labor Party might think about it and however much the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) might dissemble on the subject-which is only a polite way of saying that he is not telling the truth when he says that Australian Airlines will not be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why Australian Airlines must be sold is that a government airline, which theoretically can make a loss, cannot compete with a private airline, which cannot afford to stay in business if it makes a loss. So they both have to be put on the same ground, which inevitably means that if we get rid of the two-airline agreement Australian Airlines has to be sold. The two-airline agreement has resulted in air fares in Australia being far too high and a very great inflexibility in air services, circumstances which penalise the public enormously. So we welcome this decision.

I went on to say that the Minister simply did not understand the subject that he had blundered into. I made two points. The first referred to the Minister's claim that legislation would be applied only in relation to safety. Secondly, I said he had tunnel vision insofar as he saw all the ills of the Australian airline industry as stemming from the two-airline agreement. I made the point that we cannot legislate for safety alone. We can put all the regulations on the book about how aircraft are maintained and operated, about how crew training is done and about all the support facilities, but that does not guarantee a safe airline. We get safe airlines only when airlines are earning a profit. If airlines are to earn a profit, to some degree the Government must have an oversight over airline operations beyond that involved in safety procedures. There has to be oversight with respect to fares and schedules. I do not know the answer to that problem, but clearly I know a little more about it than the Minister does.

We on this side of the chamber support the abandonment of the Independent Air Fares Committee, which just guaranteed that neither of the airlines could go broke, no matter what happened-with the public picking up the tab. But it is very naive and simplistic for the Minister to say that the only regulation of the airline industry will be in relation to safety matters. Safety involves more than simple regulations as to the maintenance and support of aircraft. The second point I made was that a range of other issues in relation to airline operations are quite divorced from the two-airline agreement. Very quickly I will list them: curfews at Australian airports, the lack of a parallel runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, the poor standard of radar and instrument landing systems, a poor meteorological service, and at the same time featherbedding by unions representing the pilots, the cabin attendants and the ground crews.

The curfew, which applies at a number of Australian airports, and most critically at Sydney-because nearly all traffic in Australia hubs through Sydney-means that for nearly a third of the day airlines cannot use their equipment. Between the hours of 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. no aircraft, other than turbo-prop aircraft and light aircraft, can operate into Sydney Airport. It is not just that aircraft cannot get into Sydney, Brisbane and, I think, Adelaide, but aircraft cannot be positioned in another capital city to start the next day's run. An airline might want to fly a service into Brisbane or somewhere else at the end of the day and get in at midnight. It cannot do so because of the curfew. The airline might beat the curfew by coming into Brisbane at 11 p.m. but it might want to start that aircraft at 6 a.m. the following day out of Sydney-and the aircraft cannot be positioned there. Aircraft have a short life. They have to be amortised over a 10- or 15-year period because technology is progressing the whole time. So Australian operators are faced with the huge economic penalty of losing one-third of the effective life of their aircraft. In an industry as cost intensive as the airline industry, that is a burden we cannot carry.

A very significant problem for Australian air travellers is the lack of a parallel runway at Sydney. This slows down air movements enormously. I came through Sydney today from Brisbane. We were 20 minutes late out of Brisbane because of traffic congestion at Sydney, a consequence of both the runway situation and the lack of instrumentation and adequate radar. Sydney must have a parallel runway to take turbo-prop aircraft-F27s and below.

The Labor Party, which controls most of the seats around the airport, will not see to that because it is frightened of the electorate reaction. That is absolute nonsense because by putting in a parallel runway we will not increase the number of aircraft operating into Sydney; we will just put more aircraft in at the same time. The aircraft that will come in at the same time are turbo-prop aircraft and commuter aircraft, which are allowed to operate outside the curfew. So there is not a noise penalty in doing this. Six or eight years ago the Senate was told the cost of congestion at Sydney Airport. The figure then for fuel wasted was around $23m a year. I guess that the figure has more than doubled since it was given to this chamber.
