Not only is fuel burn involved but also air frame times are used up while the aircraft are flying, plus extra crew times while the aircraft are in a holding pattern, trying to get into Sydney. That puts a very significant impost on fares.

Another problem is the lack of adequate and modern radar facilities around the country. There is no excuse for the Government not picking this point up. The failure to have modern instrument landing systems means that landings can be attempted only in category 1 conditions. In category 2, category 3 and category 3A conditions, landings cannot be attempted, as they can overseas, which means that airliners using Australian airports have to carry fuel for alternates when, in another country, they would be able to land safely in adverse weather conditions. That problem is linked with very poor meteorological forecasting. Because the Government has cut back on meteorological forecasting and there is lack of resources to give a more precise definition, the people involved prophesy the worst case. If an aircraft is going from Sydney to Perth or from Tokyo to Perth and the meteorological people think there is a possibility of fog, they will forecast a 10 per cent possibility of fog. There may be nine chances out of ten that it will not occur, but the airline must cope with that situation. So it has to carry fuel for the alternate. The alternate for an aircraft going from Tokyo to Perth is Learmonth.

Aircraft make money from the payloads they carry. But the first thing one has to put in is fuel. With modern aircraft such as a Boeing 767, which is very fuel efficient, the rule of thumb is that for every three pounds of fuel an aircraft carries for an alternate, it will burn one pound, or one-third, of it just carrying that excess fuel load. So the lack of adequate radar and instrument landing facilities and the inability accurately to forecast meteorological conditions are, again, very high imposts on the Australian traveller.

I now turn to the poor productivity of Australian air crews. This is not a reflection on their professional competence in any way, but we have a high degree of overmanning. May showed in his report on an Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery that the productivity of crews in America in some cases was up to twice the level of that in Australia. Ansett Airlines of Australia is the only airline in the world that carries three on the flight deck of its 767 aircraft. It had to get the aircraft specially made for that purpose. That was because the pilots and engineers ganged up on the operator and said, `We are going to keep our jobs'. Qantas Airways Ltd operates exactly the same aircraft, and at a higher gross weight over longer stages, with only two on the flight deck.

Pilots in Australia also have very high rates of pay. I do not begrudge the salaries they get. However, whereas airline pilots around the world have taken significant cuts in their salaries in the last five to eight years, and with increased hours on duty, Australian pilots have not done that. Although there is a limited number of hours which aircrew can fly in Australia, the regulatory procedure is such that only 50 to 60 per cent of the nominal hours they can fly can be got from them because of overregulation by the Department of Transport and Communications. The whole matter of efficient and safe operation in Australia involves far wider considerations than the Minister has shown. I am sorry that he is not here. He would have learnt a little had he been in the chamber. But, characteristically, we will have to do that at a later date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the deregulation of the airline industry in Australia. I have always been amazed at the amount of regulation which exists in Australia, especially since aviation was pioneered in Australia. Kingsford-Smith and others made aviation a household word not only in Australia but around the world. Since that time, bureaucrats and various politicians have got together to hamstring aviation to the point where we have some of the most regulated airspace and aviation procedures in the world. I speak with some experience. I have been flying for 37 years as a commercial pilot and a flight instructor. I have owned my own flying business. I have been a control tower operator in the Air Force. It always annoys me that people who have no knowledge of the industry make statements. One of the statements that is being made now about deregulation is that, automatically, flying will be less safe, as has been the case in the United States of America since deregulation. However, no figures are quoted on that. I often find in Australia that when people are opposed to some facet of Australian life or some regulation they will drum up spurious figures overseas to support their cases. It is very difficult to track these down. They make sweeping statements with no justification.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the figures in the United States of America, we find that there has not been all that much of a change in terms of safety. What we find is that there has been much media attention on air crashes that take place in the United States, as is the case here and elsewhere. There is a double standard. An automobile accident, even if it kills seven people, may be buried on page three or four of a newspaper, but we often see headlines such as `Plane lands safely after engine failure', which implies somehow that the safe landing is an exceptional event when, in fact, safe landings are quite common. We never see a headline saying, `Car runs out of petrol on freeway', but we often see a headline saying, `Light plane runs out of petrol: pilot lands safely'.

What has been the safety achievement in the United States since deregulation? It turns out that taking a bath in a bathtub is more hazardous to one's health in the United States than is flying. Every year some 1,000 people in the United States die as a result of accidents in bathtubs. On average, some 500 people in the United States die because of air disasters. In the United States, there have been other happenings besides deregulation. President Ronald Reagan sacked all the controllers. That led to an influx of controllers, many of whom were unskilled and untrained, and they were forced into positions far above their degree of skill. That caused a spate of near misses and several accidents. Whatever is happening in the United States, it cannot be said that flying is now unsafe because of deregulation.

Flying is very safe in Australia, and well it should be. Australia has very low aircraft density compared with that which exists in parts of Europe, Japan and the United States. Australia has very good weather. As Senator MacGibbon pointed out, meteorological services have been cut back, but still we are blessed with very good weather compared with that in North America and Europe when, in the winter, there is freezing rain, ice on runways and snow drifts alongside runways. We certainly have far better weather than that and our safety record shows it.

The Department of Transport and Communications has often used safety as a means of extracting more money and better bureaucratic situations for its operation. I think that we have to face safety squarely. People do not like to talk about aircraft safety or any kind of safety, but we have to face the fact that people who fly can be fatally injured. There is a risk. The only way to avoid the risk is to stop flying. For years, the Department seems to have had this attitude. It was a standing joke in the industry that the only time the Department would be absolutely satisfied would be when all aeroplanes were stored permanently in hangars and the doors spot-welded shut. Now we have seen a slight cleaning out of the attitudes of the Department. It has been subjected to the scrutiny of the Dick Smith inquiry. Some 700 to 800 people made submissions to that inquiry about inadequacies in the Department which were causing unsafe practices in themselves.

One of the things that have always concerned me in Australia is the size of the control zones-the amount of area that the Department actually sets aside in primary control areas for operation in times of instrument conditions. In Hobart, the control zone is 50 miles across, which means that any aircraft transiting that zone has to be in radio contact with the tower. It has to have previous approval to cross that zone and has to be under direct control at all times. The control zone is so large that it actually extends to the opposite sides of mountain ranges so an aircraft can be flying legally in the control zone but it cannot actually contact the tower. That is absurd. In the United States, control zones are 10 miles across; they are a radius of five miles around an airport-that is, five miles radius and 10 miles diameter. In the United States, they will take a massive amount of air space-anything above 700 feet in times of instrument flying conditions. But in times of visual flight conditions, the control zones are only 10 miles across, in addition to which there are many visual flight rules (VFR) corridors across the tops of airports which require no control at all. There is a VFR corridor which goes right over the top of Los Angeles International Airport. One needs no clearance at all to transit this zone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was closed last month.

—It certainly existed for a number of years and I used it quite safely for a number of years. If it has been closed it might be because the whole of Los Angeles basin has a density of traffic which is probably many times greater than anything in Australia. Our Department of Aviation bureaucrats have always felt that the only way to maintain safety is closely to regulate air traffic. But in many instances this actually has an unsafe result. Many pilots in Australia are afraid to enter a control zone. Often they are taught that unless they use the correct language and follow the correct procedures they will in fact be penalised for entering a control zone. Since the control zones for our city airports are in basins surrounded by mountains, frequently when pilots get into trouble in bad weather, instead of going into the basin, the control zone area, they will attempt to fly around the outside and they will strike a mountain top and kill all the occupants of the aircraft. There are a number of ways in which we can increase safety without merely locking all the aircraft in hangars.

SPEECH.PARA: Another difficulty with the safe operation of aircraft and the Department of Aviation is the very strict adherence to regulations by Department of Aviation personnel. In my home State of Tasmania a pilot took off from Strahan airport. He got lost and he asked for assistance. It is a well-known mistake in Australia to ask for assistance, because if a pilot does, immediately forms are filed against him and he is asked to explain. The pilot found his way back to Strahan and landed safely. After waiting several days for the weather to clear he flew to Hobart. He was instructed by the tower that the people there wished to talk to him on the telephone when he landed. He did and they pulled his licence. Why did they pull his licence? Because he admitted that he was lost. They kept his licence until he was subject to more training. That is not the way to encourage people to adopt safe procedures. One does not penalise them for admitting that they need help or declaring emergencies. I think Senator MacGibbon will agree that one has to think twice before one declares an emergency in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't.
—Paperwork ensues from a declared emergency. One has to file a report. The tower files a report. The fire brigade files a report and there is a full investigation.
—There is an intimidatory atmosphere from the Department.

—Yes. The Department must look at this. As Senator MacGibbon has pointed out, safety cannot be legislated; it must be part of a working partnership with all in the aviation industry. I turn to the two-airline system. The two-airline system is based on a gross misconception about the aviation industry. The misconception is that one has to force airlines to fly. The reality is that if there are two groups of people anywhere on earth and two airstrips near these two groups of people somebody, somewhere will start an airline to serve these people, to fly them from one place to another. It is simply not true that the two-airline system is necessary for the movement of people and freight around Australia. If the two-airline system did not exist we would still have just as many airline seats between all population centres in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The two-airline system ensures high profits for the existing two airlines. It maintains a monopoly in what should be a free market, free enterprise industry. The two-airline system carries great penalties for the aviation industry and consumers in Australia. For the aviation industry, the two-airline system causes considerable expense in the following manner. Since Australia has such a high level of cost recovery directly attributable to the aviation industry, the users of the facilities offered by the Government are penalised financially. The two-airline system costs the industry money because the airlines operate on very close parallel scheduling. This means that the air traffic control system has to have all the sophistication of a system handling high-density traffic. Given the parallel scheduling, there are always two jet aircraft within a few minutes of each other in the airspace. In order to maintain separation and keep the safety standards, we are forced to have a system which is capable of separating great numbers of aircraft at five-minute intervals continuously. Since there are only two aircraft at five-minute intervals and the airspace is vacant at other times, the system is very uneconomic.

The other factor is the high cost of terminal buildings. With both airlines landing and taking off at similar times, the terminal facilities in places such as Hobart and Launceston have to be twice as big as they would otherwise be. For the consumer there is a dual disadvantage. One is the fact that the airlines do not swallow the cost of the cost recovery program but pass it along to the passengers. This means that they have to pay more in air fares than they otherwise would. The other disadvantage is that the passengers are forced to fly when the airlines want to fly. The airlines do not fly when the passengers necessarily want to fly. The two airlines find it most economical to load up a large jet once or twice a day, which means that the consumers-the airline passengers-have to wait hours between flights. It would be far more sensible to eliminate parallel scheduling and the two-airline system which fosters it.

Deregulation, as has occurred in the United States, is treated with loathing by aviation authorities and the two airlines in Australia. The two airlines loathe it because they have a wonderful monopoly going. They simply do not have to worry about competition. No business likes to worry about competition. Aviation officials, being bureaucrats, basically do not like change. They have learned to operate the system and they feel that anything else would be just too difficult for them to understand.

In the United States, when deregulation came in a lot of people predicted doom and gloom for the industry and said that it would be the end of aviation as we know it in America. In fact the dire predictions did not come true. Certainly there was a shake-out in the industry. A number of firms did go to the wall. Hundreds of firms started: the efficient survived, the inefficient did not. Aviation is still alive and well. New airlines have sprung up to take the place of inefficient airlines which went out of business. There has been a large turnover, a shake-out in the industry, but the consumer has benefited. To my knowledge there is no community of any size in America which is not served by aircraft. The aircraft may not be as big as previously but I do not believe that a big aircraft is necessarily better than a smaller one. In fact, I would much rather fly on a service which would supply me with a 10-passenger plane every hour at my convenience than an airliner which flies only once a day with 120 passengers on board.

The doom and gloom merchants who predicted higher air fares were proven incorrect in the United States. Fares in the United States have dropped tremendously since deregulation. At other times fares in the United States have been cited here. I will list just a few. Admittedly these are special fares but some of them are as follows: $29 from Newark, New Jersey, to Montreal; $99 from Newark to Brussels; $49 from Newark to Atlanta; and $69 from Newark to Dallas. It is interesting that the fare on a bus on the same routes actually costs more than the air fare. New markets are being developed.

Consumers and the industry will both benefit from deregulation in Australia. There is no evidence to suggest that safety would suffer. There is no rational reason that flying would be any less safe than it is now. The same high standards for aircraft and air crew would apply whether deregulation took place or not. The two airlines, once they got over the original shock of change, could find it quite stimulating to be in a competitive situation. There would be a lot of moaning and groaning on the part of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines but others such as Bob Ansett and the smaller charter firms would be quite overjoyed with deregulation. Cheaper fares would prompt a number of people to fly who are now unable to afford air fares, thus opening up a new market. Roughly 92 per cent of Australians do not fly, 8 per cent do and only 2 or 3 per cent fly with any frequency. There is a tremendous market to be tapped and it will be tapped if fares are reduced to the point where people can afford them.

We must have regulations protecting the industry from the rip-off artists: we do not want the entire industry to be a monopoly controlled by Rupert Murdoch or Sir Peter Abeles. We must have firm anti-trust legislation or some mechanism to keep the entire airline industry from falling into the hands of a small group of people. On the issue of privatisation, frankly as an American coming to Australia I was at first puzzled by the nationalised system of airlines and trains, but I have since grown accustomed to this concept and I find it really quite worth while. I do not think that Australian Airlines should be sold off and privatised. I think that the airline can compete and should be allowed to compete. It should be given the capital to expand to allow it to compete successfully in a deregulated market.

There is another aspect to deregulation, that is, the use of the many empty airline seats in Qantas aircraft which regularly cross Australia. Qantas flies between Australian cities each week with some 1,000 vacant seats which could be used for flying passengers at reduced rates. De- regulation should also allow companies such as Air New Zealand Ltd into the market. It is an irony that Ansett Airlines is allowed to operate in New Zealand, yet Air New Zealand is not allowed to operate in Australia. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, stated recently that Air New Zealand would not be able to operate domestic services in Australia. If we are to have true competition, we must change this policy and allow Air New Zealand, as well as any other airline that can furnish a service to the consumers, into the market. In closing, I would like to observe that deregulation will at last allow the aviation industry to attain its proper place in Australia's transportation system. It is about time. The Australian Democrats support this move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Government's motion to terminate the two-airline agreement. I believe that this is a long overdue development. I think that the Government is to be congratulated for taking this decision. However, I must say that I am a little bemused by Senator Messner's amendment to the motion moved by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans). I point out that, of the last 38 years of government in Australia, the Liberal-National Party coalition was in government for 30 years. It had many opportunities to end the two-airline agreement but never chose that option.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1950s and 1960s it was quite clear to many people in Australia that the two-airline agreement was being used to stifle the then Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) operation to the advantage of Australian National Airways (ANA) and later Ansett Airlines of Australia. For example, in the late 1950s TAA wanted to go straight into the use of jets. At that stage ANA could not afford that leap forward, so it convinced the Government that there ought to be a purchase of turbo-jets. From the late 1950s until about 1963 we had both airlines operating the same sort of aircraft. That was a delay that disadvantaged TAA. If TAA had been allowed to purchase jets in the late 1950s, as it wanted to, it would have been much more competitive than Ansett and been able to provide a quicker and better service. Because of the arrangement of the two-airline system in the 1950s and the desire of the Menzies coalition Government to protect Ansett, a commercially difficult decision was forced on TAA.

I refer now to paragraph (b) of Senator Messner's amendment, which relates to competition and the situation in regard to the two-airline agreement during the late 1950s and 1960s. At that time Ansett ANA was able to buy up many of the regional airline operators in Australia. In my State of South Australia it bought up Airlines of South Australia, which became a fully fledged subsidiary of that company. The same thing occurred in Western Australia when, I think, MacRobertson Miller Airlines was bought up. Ansett ANA also bought up one of the regional airlines in New South Wales. Therefore, when the issue of competition was raised during the 1960s the coalition government of the day did nothing to stop Ansett buying up regional airlines under the auspices of the two-airline agreement. Therefore, I must say that paragraph (b) of Senator Messner's amendment is a little late and is a little bemusing to us, knowing the track record of the coalition.

As I said, the issue of the two-airline agreement comes back to the fact that the coalition, in government for 30 out of 38 years, did not take the opportunity offered. Now that the Federal Labor Government has taken the decision, there is in the Opposition almost an attitude of crying over spilt milk. There is a sense of regret and chagrin that this action has been taken by the Labor Government and that the coalition parties have again been forced to admit that this is an appropriate way in which to go in the development of the aviation industry in Australia. I think that the Senate should reject out of hand Senator Messner's amendment and pass Senator Evans's motion concerning notice of termination of the two-airline agreement. Senator Messner's amendment is at the very least gratuitous.

Debate in the community about the two-airline agreement and the future of the civil aviation industry revolves around two items: deregulation and privatisation. I do not hold with the view that deregulation in any way is necessarily connected to privatisation, or vice versa. I believe that deregulation is a separate issue, and it is one that I fully support in the way that it has been put forward by the Government. Deregulation is the process of removing regulations which unnecessarily restrict the operations of an organisation. Privatisation is the transfer of public assets to the private sector. The motion deals purely with deregulation. The Minister's statement outlines the form of an inquiry to be undertaken on the future of Australian Airlines. I will come back to that in a moment. However, in no circumstances is that a forerunner to a privatisation program. It is to deal with the most effective way for Australian Airlines to operate in this community.

Like Senator Sanders, formerly an American citizen but now an Australian citizen, I recently had an opportunity to experience the American aviation system. With Senator Puplick and Senator Bishop I visited America in January this year as part of a delegation invited by the American Government. In 2 1/2 weeks of flying around America we had the opportunity to see, one could say, the best and the worst of the deregulated American civil aviation industry. I would have to say that a number of aspects of the deregulated American civil aviation industry can be supported. There is no doubt that, as far as the cost of air fares is concerned, many more people on lower incomes in America can afford to fly compared to the number in Australia who can afford to do so. The air fares that Senator Sanders read out are typical of some of those available to people. When Kenneth Galbraith was visiting Australia recently he was asked specifically whether he was in favour of deregulation. He said that on a case to case basis he supported some deregulations and opposed others but that on balance he supported deregulation of the aviation industry in America because it meant that a greater number of ordinary people had access to flying than had the opportunity before deregulation took place. He said that that was to be supported. That was a comment from one of the most liberal and Keynesian economists in the world. It is interesting to note that Galbraith supported deregulation because it gave people in the community a more equitable chance to fly.

I do not know whether the figures that Senator Sanders quoted are correct, but I think they are pretty close to it. In Australia only about 8 per cent of people regularly fly and maybe only 2 or 3 per cent fly consistently. Probably senators and members in the other place are the most regular users of air transport in Australia. Therefore, we all have a vested interest in air transport. We are part of the lucky 2 or 3 per cent who use air transport as part of our parliamentary duties.

The aspect of deregulation in America which I think has to be queried and looked at very carefully in the Australian context relates to the level of service that is provided. I do not want to give a Cook's tour about what happened to me in the 2 1/2 weeks I was in America but I must say that, on a couple of occasions, trying to catch an American domestic jet was almost equivalent to catching the subway in New York in terms of services. The only things that were missing were graffiti on the inside walls of the plane and the chance of being mugged. I understand that no one travelling on a jet aircraft has been mugged, although I suspect that that sort of thing may not be too far away having regard to the level of servicing and staffing of the civil aviation industry in America.

Passengers on Australian aircraft have reasonable expectations in good weather of being able to make a connecting flight within 10 or 15 minutes of arrival at an airport. In good weather in America one runs a great risk, almost a certain risk, of missing one's connection. The timetables that apply when one books one's flight really might as well have been drawn out of a hat. When I booked my ticket in Washington I was told that to catch a plane at 8.45 a.m. I should be at the airport just after 7 a.m. I thought that that was a pretty extraordinary allowance to make. However, when I got to the airport just after 7 a.m., I soon found out why. There was a queue about 100 yards long of passengers waiting to check in baggage and be given seat allocation. I waited in the queue for 45 minutes to get my ticket, to be allocated a seat and to hand in my luggage. Ten minutes after I had done that, it was announced: `Will all those who are flying Eastern Air Lines please go to desk number so and so. Your flight now has been cancelled. You have been transferred to United Air Lines to go via another destination'. That plane, of course, was an hour and a half late taking off. I was supposed to go to Denver, Colorado, but my luggage ended up in Boise, Idaho. As I say, I do not want to give a Cook's tour of what happened to me, but that is an example of what those of us in the delegation discovered about the level of service provided in America under that country's deregulated system.

I notice that recently in America the airlines have been asking the American Congress to amend the civil aviation legislation so as to stop people suing airlines for loss of luggage, for loss of time and for timetables not being adhered to. By way of civil actions, which are quite popular in America, the public was starting to sue airlines for not getting them to business appointments on time, for losing luggage and so on. Many members of juries, who had also experienced similar problems, were more than willing to award substantial payments to the people who were suing. These airlines, which are great supporters of deregulation, have tried to get out of this by asking the Government to intervene to stop the public from suing them. I find that an ironical commentary on people who so strongly support deregulation. The one thing they do not want to be responsible for is a commitment to their passengers to deliver them on time.

One area of the American system that has been commented on, and in respect of which I think there is less concern, is air safety. Certainly many of us in Australia and elsewhere had some apprehensions about flying to America after Ronald Reagan sacked 11,000 air traffic controllers in 1981-82.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in the union movement.

—Yes. It is interesting that in 1979-80 the air traffic controllers' union was one of only two unions that endorsed Ronald Reagan for election as the President of America. The other union was, of course, the Teamsters Union. Most of us who are involved in the broad labour movement in this country do not consider the Teamsters Union to be a trade union; it is more like a vehicle for organised crime. But, as I said, the air traffic controllers supported Ronald Reagan's election. They openly endorsed him and made contributions to his campaign. They thought that they were going to get from him a commitment in regard to an increase in salaries. But 12 months later they paid the penalty by all being sacked.

SPEECH.PARA: We had many concerns about safety in the American airline industry but the figures show that, since deregulation, safety in terms of the number of passengers flown has improved. I will cite the figures. Measured in terms of passenger fatalities per billion revenue passenger miles, passenger accidents in the United States actually fell from an average of 0.86 per billion during 1969-78, pre-deregulation, to an average of 0.32 per billion during 1979-85, post-deregulation. Although I do not suggest in any way that the American system of air safety and air traffic control is one that we ought to emulate in this country, it has to be admitted that there is evidence that safety is not the problem some people in Australia say that it is.

I now turn to the question of industrial relations in America. When the airlines were deregulated, many employees were sacked as a result of mergers. Many took or were forced to take reductions in pay. However, over the last couple of years evidence has emerged that by and large employees in the industry are earning and enjoying pro rata salaries and conditions to employees working in other industries in America. So I think the American experience in respect of deregulation ought to be looked at very closely.

But when we read the statement made by the Minister for Transport and Communications in support of the termination of the two-airline agreement, we find that we are not going down the same road as the Americans and, in my view, we ought to be grateful that we are not. We should look at the American experience and take the best of what happened there. One matter I should raise is the cost of air fares. I come from South Australia, which is very dependent upon access to air transport from Adelaide to the eastern States and to Western Australia. We do not have access to the range of international flights that the eastern States or even Western Australia have. We have a limited number of international flights but many people in South Australia still have to fly to Melbourne or Sydney to connect with international flights. Therefore, we in South Australia are very sensitive about the cost of air fares. It is proposed that the Independent Air Fares Committee be ended and that power be exercised under the Trade Practices Act and by the Prices Surveillance Authority. I would be concerned to ensure that after deregulation the Prices Surveillance Authority would act with considerable determination to ensure that air fares in this country are kept at a reasonable level.

Many years ago railway fares were the main concern to the public of Australia and in other Western countries because rail was the major form of passenger transport. Now, the cost of air fares in both our country and the rest of the world is critical because aviation is the means by which most people choose to move around their own country or the international sphere. Therefore, the Prices Surveillance Authority in particular has to be firm and direct in discussing and negotiating the cost of air fares with the airlines. It will be what are called the BAPH States, the outlying States, which will suffer greatly in the deregulated atmosphere if the air fare prices are allowed to rise substantially. The smaller States will be greatly disadvantaged. Deregulation and competition may substantially reduce prices on the Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Canberra air routes, but the outlying States will have a problem.

I must expand that statement to say that our continent is nearly the same size as the USA but we have only 17 million people. The United States, which is only slightly larger, has about 250 million people. The density of population to provide customers for the air transport system is quite different. Therefore, the deregulation of our industry has to take into account that we have a vast continent with a sparse population. For the regional areas of Australia, even outside the major capital cities of the smaller States, how we provide air services in the deregulated economy and the deregulated system will be critical. I am sure that from time to time members of parliament of all political persuasions will raise questions about the provision of efficient, cheap air services to regional areas of Australia. However successful deregulation is in the major areas, I suspect that there will be a number of queries that we will have to deal with. These may well lead one day to the Parliament and the Government having to make a decision to support a subsidy to the regional areas of Australia so that reasonable air services can be provided to those communities.

The final matter to which I wish to refer is the question of so-called privatisation. When Australian Airlines was established by the Chifley Government, it was for a very specific reason. At that stage it looked as though there could be a monopoly of the Australian airline services by the then Australian National Airways-ANA. One of the major reasons that the Chifley Government established Australian Airlines, as it is now known, was to provide competition by ensuring that two airlines would be operating in Australia. I have already mentioned that I believe that, during the 23 years of the coalition Government, the two-airline system was often perverted to support Ansett Airlines of Australia unnecessarily. Although the situation of civil aviation in Australia now is quite different from 1949, I still believe that Australian Airlines has every justification to continue to be an airline service in which the Australian people, through the Government, maintain a majority role. Because of the importance of civil aviation and air transport to the development of our country, a very important social priority can be justified and put forward for this airline to stay substantially in public ownership. I agree that there will obviously be some problems for Australian Airlines in raising the finance which it needs to equip itself, whether deregulated or not, to meet the challenge of the 1990s.

The Federal Government, in announcing general deregulation, has already outlined some measures to improve the commercial operation of Australian Airlines. These include the incorporation and removal of day to day controls, which I think will obviously be important to give the airline an immediate sense that it is in charge of its own affairs. In regard to the removal of the need for the Minister to sign all but the major and significant expenditure decisions, Senator Evans referred, at a meeting this week which I attended, to some of the items for which he has to sign and approve-matters which are really day to day management decisions of the airline. Irrespective of the argument about whether privatisation should occur, these things are unnecessarily bureaucratic and affect the efficiency of the airline. Those sorts of changes in Australian Airlines will improve its efficiency and its competitiveness.

The most important matter that Senator Evans has announced is the establishment of an advisory group to examine the remaining questions about how Australian Airlines can optimise its managerial effectiveness in the post-deregulated environment. I think it would be very difficult for people to complain about the expertise and background of members of the advisory group.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has Peter Redlich got going for him?

—Senator Alston may not be aware that Peter Redlich is a senior legal person from Victoria who-whether Senator Alston likes it or not; I openly admit it-is a former President of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party.
—That is all he has got going for him.
—For 23 years, and a subsequent seven years, Senator Alston's Party was in government. Some of the appointments that were made in that time--
—You started out saying that they were well qualified. I am asking for the qualifications.

—I openly say that Peter Redlich, with his legal experience as well as his political experience, is well qualified to serve on the committee. I make no bones about it. I do not presume that Senator Alston would say that Ted Harris, as Chairman of Ampol Ltd and also of the Australian Airlines Board, does not have some experience and knowledge of transport in Australia. I do not suppose that he would object to Peter Wilenski, the head of the Department, who has a long experience of public--
—Harris is hardly objective as the incoming Chairman of the Board.

—We are not looking at destroying Australian Airlines by setting up this committee, which is maybe what Senator Alston wants to do. We are trying to put together a committee with expertise and background both in public administration and in private enterprise administration. Senator Alston would obviously strongly object to Bill Kelty being a member of the inquiry.
—He is on for a different reason.

—He is there for the very good reason that several thousand people employed by Australian Airlines all happen to be members of appropriate trade unions. Bill Kelty is a representative of trade unions in Australia.
—He flies around with lots of government boards and authorities.

—It must irk Senator Alston that this Government will take the opportunity to appoint people such as Bill Kelty. We accept the fact that trade unions have a legitimate and effective part to play in the Australian community. When Opposition senators were in government they tried to ignore trade unions and cut them out of playing any role at all. That is the way in which they want to operate. They just want to appoint business people to boards, inquiries and so on, and not give the trade union movement any representation. We give both sides representation, as well as the public administration. The terms of reference for the advisory group are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to advise the Government, against the possibility of either the removal or retention of the board-ranging controls I have already referred to, on:
(a) the extent of Australian Airline's capital requirements, and options for meeting these requirements; and
(b) means of enhancing the airline's management flexibility and effectiveness, and the efficiency of its operating structures.

The advisory group will generate options and hard data across a range of possibilities for the future. I believe that the way in which the Government has gone about handling the difficulties which Australian Airlines faces with its future financial requirements is the correct procedure. It is a balanced way. It will enable the Government and the community to assess, in the end, the information as to the best way in which Australian Airlines should proceed in the future. I would be extremely surprised if the recommendations of that committee are not acceptable to the Australian community. I would also be very surprised if there is not a retention for Australian Airlines to maintain a major shareholding in the public interest. I know some honourable senators opposite are not overly interested in preserving the public interest. When the coalition was in government in the 1950s and 1960s it used the two-airline agreement to act not in the public interest, but in the interests of Ansett in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong.

—I gave examples earlier in my remarks about how the two-airline agreement was used in the 1950s and 1960s to advantage Reg Ansett. The ultimate advantage Reg Ansett got was a Bill put into the Parliament of Victoria in 1971 by Sir Henry Bolte to stop another group of capitalists taking him over; namely, Sir Peter Abeles through Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd. Sir Rupert Murdoch came in later. This Government will protect the community and the public interest. Our record is immeasurably better than the record of the previous coalition government over 30-odd years of the last 38. I commend Senator Evans's motion. I certainly ask the Senate to reject the amendment moved by Senator Messner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the airlines agreement termination statement and the motion moved by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) recently. I think it is worth saying that the Government has finally grasped one part of the nettle very gingerly. It has had 4 1/2 years in which to ruminate on the desirability of freeing up the airline industry. What has ultimately emerged is little more than a damp squib.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps whilst Senator Schacht is still in the chamber it might be worth my while repeating some of the remarks I made on the last occasion in relation to the composition of the committee of review. It is quite clear to all those who take an intelligent interest in the matter that this is no ordinary committee; this is a committee of political operators and it is a deliberate part of the Government's strategy to soften up the trade union movement. One can perfectly well understand why it has been necessary for the Government to engage in verbal subterfuge to date and undoubtedly, if it were serious about inquiring into the capital base of the organisation and determining means of efficiency, then it would have taken notice of a number of well qualified experts who have already spoken on the matter. The people who would be best placed to know would be Mr Ted Harris and Mr Neil Smith, who is standing down as Chairman of Australian Airlines. Both people are already on record as saying that what is urgently needed is a significant capital injection to lift Australian Airlines not only off the ropes, but off the canvas in order to enable it to compete.

It is perfectly clear to anyone who has had even a passing interest in the industry that Australian Airlines is being taken to the cleaners and is simply not able to compete against Ansett Airlines of Australia. But what we have had here is, in effect, a holding mechanism put into place which will further disadvantage Australian Airlines by the mere passage of time. The Government hopes that this will give it sufficient breathing space prior to the next Australian Labor Party national conference to enable this committee of so-called political wise men to somehow persuade their broader union colleagues that there are some real necessities, if not political advantages, in opening up the structure of Australian Airlines.

There is simply no logical reason why it is necessary to corporatise unless one proposes at a later point to transfer at least part of that corporate structure to the private sector. If one looks at the demands that will be placed on the Government for capital injection of orders of magnitude that simply are not available, it is clear that the Government will desperately need to find a substantial sum of money in accordance with the already received recommendations of both Mr Harris and Mr Smith.

I just want to deal with a couple of other competing statutory authorities to demonstrate the level of funding that will be required if they are all to be kept in the public sector. It is very opportune that in answer to a question today Senator Evans spoke in relation to Qantas Airways Ltd I do not purport to quote him directly, but I did take some notes. He said that Qantas will have a major funding requirement of the order of $4 billion over five years. There will be a necessary capital injection, apart from internally generated funding, of some $400m which will be needed probably around 1989. He said it has a formidable capitalisation problem and, therefore, Qantas has, quite properly, engaged in forward planning in order to determine the appropriate mix-presumably he means debt and equity. It is also desirable that the Government should consider the appropriate structure of Qantas for the future.

The Government in this statement that we are debating at present has ruled out a merger between Qantas and Australian Airlines. Again, it is regrettable, I suppose, that that sort of decision should have been made prior to this so-called committee of experts. If we are serious about its charter being to investigate means of broadening the capital base, then that is one possible alternative that deserves to be explored in some detail instead of being dismissed at the outset. Again, it simply lends force to the argument that this committee is not there to make any sensible assessment of the needs of Australian Airlines, it is simply there to soften up the union movement to persuade Mr Kelty that there are some real virtues.

I noticed, incidentally, I think in today's Press, that Mr Kelty came out and defended the private sector and said that that was where real growth for the future would lie. It is clear that Mr Kelty is a highly intelligent union official who does have a very acute understanding of the needs of additional funding for public sector organisations. He also realises the very real and expanding role that needs to be played by the private sector. But because of those in the trade union movement who are not quite as enlightened, it is obviously going to take time for him to get the message across. We will find that there will be resistance from various sections of the Labor Party and the union movement to concepts of privatisation. That is not a simple proposition of selling off a public sector enterprise. In various ways capital shares can be made available. The Bank of New Zealand recently had 13 per cent of its capital structure made available to the private sector. I note that New Zealand steel is up for grabs at present. In many ways the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is attracted to the New Zealand path and was led towards prosperity by Roger Douglas. No doubt, he has absorbed a number of the lessons. One lesson is political deceit because time and again the New Zealand Government led the public to believe that it was only a limited exercise or that it did not contemplate any form of privatisation, but continued to move down that path.

That is what we are seeing with the present Government. It is terrified to use the word privatisation. It is prepared to contemplate sales of assets, but Senator Evans has gone out of his way to make it very clear that privatisation is not on the agenda. No doubt Senator Schacht was greatly relieved to be able to draw a very firm distinction between deregulation and privatisation and to somehow be satisfied, at least to date, that the Government is only in the business of deregulation. I can assure him that in due course we will see much more than deregulation not just in the area of the airlines in order to accommodate the acute capital funding problem that I have referred to in relation to Qantas, but the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, for instance, has recently received a report prepared by a consultant on behalf of its own in-house trade union which indicates that the Commonwealth Bank will need a capital injection of the order $300m or $500m if it is to remain viable and to compete with all the other sharks in the field.

For example, Aussat is in desperate need of additional capitalisation. The sums of money there are very substantial. Aussat, which currently is operating at a loss, is highly geared and will need to raise an additional $600m in the very near future to pay for the second generation of satellites, for which tenders will shortly be called. Although Telecom Australia is 71 per cent internally funded, it will clearly need more and more capital in order not only to maintain high standards of equipment within Australia but also, if it is to get into the business of exports, to reach the levels of research, development and innovation that are taken for granted in telecommunications organisations in Europe. It will need massive injections of capital.

If we add up all those sorts of figures, we are talking in excess of $2 billion capital. It is clear that, although against that aggregate sum the $200m-odd that Australian Airlines needs is not as large as that required by other statutory authorities, it is money that the Government would claim that it does not have and money that the Government does not need to raise. Apart from the political odium attached to, and the consequences that flow to, the public sector borrowing requirement from the additional capital raised, the fact is that any of the statutory authorities will be severely constrained by the limitations which remain in place, not just for those enterprises that have not yet been dealt with. We are still awaiting a comprehensive statement on government business trading enterprises.

It is deeply disappointing that the Minister did not take the opportunity to set Australian Airlines free. It has been said that there has been removal of day to day controls and that there will be removal of broader controls, but this is not so. It is not accurate to talk in terms of deregulation of Australian Airlines and putting it on a basis comparable to that of Ansett and treating it as though it is in the private sector although it is protected because of its official status. The reality is that it will still need to have ministerial approval for loan raising and decisions of significant economic magnitude. In the last financial year Telecom needed to get the approval of the Minister 82 times. I do not know how many times Australian Airlines has asked for, let alone had to receive, Government approval. It certainly got a capital injection in 1983. However, when such constraints are in place, it is often futile to make an official approach because one is made well aware in advance that the Minister will not entertain the request. It is not even valid to look at the number of occasions on which a request has been made. As the Minister made a point of saying in his statement, there has been no removal of requirement for Loan Council consideration. That is a significant detriment to Australian Airlines.

The Minister also said that the Government proposes to take further steps in relation to broader controls and that these controls involve borrowings by enterprises being subject to Loan Council consideration, remuneration of board members and senior executives being determined by the Remuneration Tribunal, industrial relations arrangements being subject to Government oversight and co-ordination and certain restrictions being placed on the ability of business enterprise to adopt commercial superannuation arrangements. What all that means is that Australian Airlines is still hamstrung. It has one and a half hands tied behind its back because it still has to comply with all the award requirements and all the generous workers' compensation arrangements that apply in the public sector, the extraordinarily generous superannuation provisions that operate and all those industrial relations responses that can be second guessed by the relevant Minister. It is simply inaccurate to say that somehow, as a result of this decision, Australia Airlines will be freed up and enabled to compete in the way that Ansett Airlines does.

Without dwelling on the point, I make it clear that there are those in the community, including senatorial aspirants such as Mr Halfpenny, who say that this is all part of Abelising the industry and is all designed simply to advantage Ansett. Whether or not that is the purpose of the motivation, one is justified in saying that may well be the end result. Recently, we have seen Australian Airlines going backwards. It has had effectively to renege on a $600m airbus purchase which it had been contractually bound to buy. It was only as a result of Mr James Strong traipsing around Europe for some weeks that eventually it was given the ability to defer the purchase as long as it maintained its deposit and accepted a continuing obligation to purchase those airbuses within the next 10 years. The bottom line is that Australian Airlines is broke, unable to go ahead with that purchase and therefore unable to upgrade its fleet.

At the same time, Ansett is in the process of announcing that it is spending $1 billion on purchases of new air fleet equipment. That creates a massive imbalance. If we look at what has happened in recent times to the structures of these two enterprises, we find that Australian Airlines is going nowhere while Ansett is going everywhere. Ansett has bought out not only East-West Airlines. That purchase is subject to the Trade Practices Commission, but I am not holding my breath for a favourable outcome in terms of competition or consumer benefits. It has taken over Lloyd aviation, which was hitherto a rapidly expanding airline. It controls Kendall Airlines, which was quite an aggressive small charter operator. It has taken over Aeropelican Air Services, which was another charter operator, between Newcastle and Sydney. As was pointed out earlier, it was only in the last few years that we saw the demise of South Australian Airlines and MacRobertson Miller Airlines-all gobbled up by the major predator.

TALK.START.PARA: —South Australian Airlines was an Ansett subsidiary which collapsed. Get your facts right.

—The end result is that there is no small charter operator in South Australia, and Ansett once again dominates the regional airlines and is in the business of gobbling up all those who might have posed a potential threat to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Against that background, what one would think would be needed, if it were desirable to inject new competition, would be quickly to transfer Australian Airlines to the private sector to enable it to compete on equal terms, to rid it of all this red tape and industrial relations nonsense that hamstrings it, and to allow it to have a decent capital injection and to go to the capital markets, not having to worry about the Loan Council or the public sector borrowing requirement to enable it to get on with the game. Of course, the trade practices monopoly provisions would operate and we would hope-Senator Evans has certainly expressed this view-that there would be no prospect of Ansett being able to take it over. We may find that it is taken over by others. Although it might start off in the hands of its employees and others, it might quickly find that it has become part of a larger organisation. I do not think that that is anything that we should deplore. It is no reason why we should not closely monitor and, if necessary, regulate the outcome. To say that it is not desirable to ensure that Australian Airlines is able to compete on an equal footing is playing into the hands of Ansett Airlines.
A good editorial appeared in the Australian Financial Review on Thursday, 8 October last. What that editorial had to say about Senator Evans's wimp of a statement was this:

. . . its timid approach to the idea of more immediate and draconian deregulation is almost certainly influenced by the very real tide of traditional Labor Party opinion opposing anything that would weaken Government intervention in the industry.

It was a brave new world when Mr Keating was prepared to deregulate the banking sector to float the dollar and allow for real and genuine competition, but now, four and a half years on, that burst of deregulatory fever has disappeared and we are seeing an ossified government. Perhaps that is inevitable after 4 1/2 years, but it is nonetheless regrettable. New Zealand was prepared to allow Ansett to shake up its domestic airline industry, but we are not prepared to allow little New Zealand Airlines to come here and return the favour.

There is nothing wrong with allowing the entrance of foreign airlines. Indeed, Scandinavian Airlines Systems, SAS, exercises domestic and international rights for Sweden, Denmark and Norway. That has been a very healthy development. It benefits not only the owners of the airline-in that instance, the Swedish Government-but also consumers because, when there is very real competition in a series of countries, consumers are the beneficiaries. That is why I think it is deeply disappointing that the Australian Government was not prepared to allow New Zealand Airlines to enter Australia's airline industry. It could have allowed in a number of other carriers, but again there are very severe restrictions-I think the limit is 15 per cent-on the involvement of foreign carriers in Australia's airline industry, and the Foreign Investment Review Board would no doubt keep a very watchful eye on the activities of any foreign entrants to the market. So there will be very little competition. Senator Evans does not pretend for a moment that there will be anything more than an incremental change. The most that he could talk about was niche carriers entering the industry. That is all very well on some trunk lines and intercapital routes, but there is absolutely no reason why we should not have competition right across the board.

There are a number of other ways in which the statement is disappointing. A major disappointment is the failure to envisage a bigger and more competitive role for Qantas in both overseas and domestic airline services. We may well, as Senator Evans intimated today, be going to have a comprehensive Government review of the operations of Qantas. Given its capital requirements, perhaps that is long overdue. That is another issue that could have been addressed in the context of Australian Airlines, but all we had was the statement that any merger would be ruled out. This policy will not do much more than enable Australian Airlines to retain a very real and significant competitive advantage. I think that is regrettable. In large measure it is because the Government is still hide-bound by its opposition to privatisation and by its fear of hastening too fast for the trade union movement. The rationale for public ownership of a domestic airline has long since disappeared. We have to go back to 1945 and the unsuccessful attempt by the then Labor Government to nationalise the provision of air services to detect the origins of what was then Trans Australia Airlines. It was a result of a political compromise when the Menzies Government came to power that the two airlines agreement came into existence.

If what we are talking about in current economic circumstances is generating a more effective and efficient national economy, both public and private sectors have to play their part. There is no reason at all why a domestic carrier need be owned by government. I am sure that Senator Evans acknowledges that point but, for base political reasons, he is not prepared to move down the necessary path of allowing the govern- ment airline to compete in the way it ought to be allowed, and will ultimately need, to compete if it is not to shrivel and wither on the vine.

The justification for public ownership of domestic airlines was thought to lie in increased air safety providing genuine competition because somehow the public sector would be more honourable and honest and keep the private sector up to the mark. I do not think anyone pretends these days that the existence of a public firm in an industry in any way acts as an aid to economic regulation or to inspire competition. For many years we have had the soft life and non-price competition, and that to a very limited extent. In the United States of America there have been significant benefits, not just, as Galbraith would concede, directly in enabling more people to fly. That is probably a function of the reduced costs of flying, passed on as benefits to the consumer in terms of air fares. What has tended to happen in a regulated environment is that any benefits that might be extracted by monopoly players such as Australian Airlines have resulted in cost padding, probably feather bedding in terms of employees and all sorts of non-price benefits that have flowed on to all but consumers. It is certainly the view of Michael Kirby, not the one that Senator Puplick would have in mind but an economist who has specialised in the airline industry for many years--

TALK.START.PARA: —My Michael Kirby would have had a view too!

—He has certainly done enough international travelling to qualify as an expert, but perhaps in his current role he is not truly regarded as an economist. The Michael Kirby I refer to, in a publication released several weeks ago, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the cost efficiency of . . . US local service and trunk airlines increased significantly following deregulation . . . Cost differences of the order of 25-30 per cent have been observed between new entrants and established carriers. These differences have been attributed to a less unionised workforce with lower wages and conditions . . .

Bear in mind that employees in the United States have been prepared to take real cuts in wages-nominal wages. That is because of an entirely different corporate culture, no doubt, but it is also because they have had a vested interest in seeing the industry survive. In some instances perhaps it has not survived, but their action shows a breadth of vision and a willingness to accept the risks that simply have not prevailed in Australia. Kirby went on to say:

These differences have been attributed to . . . fewer senior staff, and increased aircraft utilisation achieved through higher seating densities, the use of less congested airports, specialised `no frills' services and simpler network patterns.

So a number of significant benefits will flow from genuine competition and deregulation. The tragedy in this statement is that we do not really have anything like genuine deregulation, let alone the anathema of privatisation. To that extent, this statement is a very disappointing document. So much could have been done to enable Australian Airlines to get back on to a sound footing, whether or not it went into the private sector. I would argue that it should and that that is where it should already be. But even if the justification for corporatisation was that it would somehow then be on an equal footing, the reality is that in all sorts of ways it remains hamstrung and does not have the capital that it requires.

Senator Evans, in the context of a review of Qantas, will no doubt be prepared to review some of the capital requirements of Australian Airlines, but government has a massive task ahead of it if it has to find something like $2 billion which it does not have. The reality is obvious that it will have to privatise, in whole or in part, a significant number of public statutory authorities and trading enterprises. Australian Airlines is probably the easiest one of all. There are probably fewer ideological reasons, let alone commercial reasons, why we need in this day and age a publicly-owned domestic airline, yet, when the opportunity was provided, all that Senator Evans could do was to conform to what has been conventional wisdom for the last 4 1/2 years and give notice of the termination of the two airlines agreement. Beyond that we have seen very little indeed. We have had a cautious and timid response to some very real opportunities.

The end result of all that is that there will continue to be one major player which will go from strength to strength and one lesser player which will remain hamstrung by remaining in the government sector, and in the meantime consumers will get much the worst of the deal. The statement is, therefore, very disappointing. I can only hope that, in the fullness of time and with the political wisdom that undoubtedly resides in those on the committee of review, strength of purpose and political will will be found to enable the Government to take what it knows to be the right commercial and political decision for the benefit of all Australians, which it has not yet had the courage to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly join the debate on the motion by Senator Gareth Evans. As a National Party senator, I have to support anything that offers deregulation, privatisation or something in that direction. But I have some misgivings about this motion. I am concerned about a number of areas. As a senator and member of parliament who uses the airlines extensively, I certainly acknowledge and am very grateful for the service given by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines. It is nice to know when one gets on an aircraft that one can make a connection within 15 or 20 minutes of arrival. There are delays from time to time but I believe that the services these two airlines offer to Australia are second to none in the world. I am very happy to say that publicly.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that we may move to a monopoly situation. We have heard from previous speakers that Australian Airlines has been hamstrung and does not have the money or financial support to provide services equal to those of Ansett. As a National Party senator, and as a senator who gets a lot of electoral support from remote Australia, I must say that I am concerned about how the policy of the Department of Transport and Communications on the abolition of the two-airline agreement, an open skies policy, will affect remote Australians-not the people on the main routes between Brisbane and Sydney and between Sydney and Melbourne. I believe that the two-airline agreement was set up early in the 1950s to subsidise air travel in the rural areas of Australia. In other words, the profits picked up on the main routes between the major cities could be offset against the losses sustained in servicing the more remote areas. Information given by Senator Evans indicates that since 1968 the towns and cities serviced by the two major airlines have been reduced in number from 150 to 80. Therefore, the two-airline agreement has fallen down in its objective to service the more remote areas. Therefore, the airlines no longer really deserve the protection of the community.

I listened very carefully to Senator Schacht's contribution. He pointed out that the airline services to remote areas will be run on a completely free enterprise system. That concerns me because I believe-and I have always said this-that for free enterprise to exist we must have competition. If competition is lacking in airline services to places such as Longreach, Barcaldine and Winton, there will be a monopoly if the Government leaves the airlines to set their own prices. What will eventually happen in those areas is that cities and towns will not be able to sustain two airlines. They will be able to sustain only one service and that service will then have a monopoly in that area. A monopoly will generate very high air fares.

Many people in remote areas of Queensland and western New South Wales do not even enjoy a telephone service. They depend very heavily on a reliable airline service for communication with cities and other areas. I believe that these people will lose under this deregulated airline system. I would like to ask Senator Evans, who has joined us in the chamber, whether he has made any provision for people living in remote areas. Only this year, the Federal Government reduced a $7m subsidy to the people of outback western Queensland. That caused a prominent airline to remove its service from the western areas of Queensland, leaving a large number of western Queensland graziers and farmers without any form of air transport. It was only through luck that another airline was prepared to fill the gap left by Australian Airlines. Whilst Flightwest provides a very good service-I have no complaints about it, and I have travelled with Flightwest-it uses a smaller plane and the service and the number of flights have been reduced. People are travelling in far less comfort than they were when the area was serviced by the previous airline. These are the types of concerns that I have. What will be the consequences for these rural people of a deregulated airline industry?

Mr Halfpenny has said that we will see the monopolisation of the airline system. That is already happening. A great number of the smaller airlines have been taken over by Ansett. Senator Alston mentioned six or seven of them. Every airline that has serviced smaller areas has been bought out by a major operator to provide on-traffic. So we are facing a crisis now in that we are seeing less competition in the airline market than we have seen before in the history of air services in Australia. This must concern everyone in the Senate. Rather than the opening up of airline services to many other competitors, we will see a reduction in the number of players providing services for air commuters. If there were a search of the number of airline companies in Australia, we would find that the number has fallen fairly drastically over the last three or four years. All we are left with is the major airlines-Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines. When there was a chance of some competition from East-West Airlines Ltd-East-West was the only player in the field that could have provided any competition for the two major airlines-it was snaffled by Sir Peter Abels. He reduced the chance of any competition coming in that would have provided an alternative to Ansett and Australian Airlines.

I am mindful of the fact that the cost of air fares in Australia is high. I am surprised that Senator Evans's document says that deregulation of the airlines will reduce the cost of air transport in Australia by only 7 to 10 per cent. I would have thought that overseas experience would have shown that the reduction in air fares would have been considerably more than that. Nevertheless, I support the main thrust of the document which has been put down by the Government. I am concerned about some of the results that could lead from the document and I ask the Government to take on board the experiences of the United States of America. From my reading of the situation over there, rather than the airline business being expanded when the airlines were deregulated, there was a great falling out and it went down to four or five major players in the airline business.

I express my concern for the people of remote Australia. We have a large continent with a very small population in the hinterland which, it would seem to me, is unable to support a number of air services going into those smaller areas. Obviously, that could lead to a monopoly situation in areas such as Longreach, Winton, Mareeba and the many airports in New South Wales, western Victoria, northern South Australia and eastern Western Australia. If there is a complete deregulation of air fares, I am concerned that the cost will rise and some people in those remote areas will not have the capacity to pay fares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to track over every one of the issues that have been raised in the course of this rather discursive debate. I note simply that strong general support has been expressed for the Government's deregulation policy and, accordingly, for the specific terms of the motion to terminate the two airlines agreement. I will confine my remarks to saying something about the comparative position in the United States (US) which has been the subject of so much speculation, particularly in the media. Many spectres have been raised by a number of people that this might be the downside of the Australian deregulatory environment. Having made some remarks about the United States, I will turn specifically to the terms of the Opposition's amendment to the motion and explain why it is that it really is a rather misconceived set of whinges that are there set out.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say just a word or two about the US situation, because there has been, not to any great extent in this chamber but certainly in a lot of other places, a disposition to suggest that there are some real risks in following a deregulatory course, given some of the less happy features of the United States experience. The Australian Government has been acutely conscious of a number of the difficulties that have occurred in the US following deregulation there in 1978, and our policy is designed to avoid the undesirable effects of the kind of economic de- regulation that occurred in that country. Critics of deregulation in the United States have focused on a number of matters. For example, they point to the fact that the benefits, such as higher frequency of service and lower fares, have not been uniformly available. They also argue that consumer benefits have been achieved largely at the expense of reduced wages and conditions of employment in the aviation industry. Concerns are also expressed about the lower levels of in-flight service which have accompanied lower fares, the congestion of airports and airways facilities, with delays and costs to industry and consumers that have resulted from large traffic growth, and possible threats to safety standards. More recently, criticism has been directed to the dominance of the market by relatively few airlines through a process of mergers and acquisitions.

These criticisms need to be put into proper perspective, I believe, by looking at the economic and industrial environment in the United States during the period of deregulation. In the early stages of deregulation in the US, the economy in that country was at a very low point with double digit inflation, used aircraft freely available, a large pool of skilled unemployed aviation industry workers and fluctuating interest rates. Existing operators, financially weakened by the economic recession, were thus in a very poor position to prevent the entrance of large numbers of new operators and they did come in droves-some 100 new entrants to the interstate market alone. They did not always come for very long, but long enough, certainly, to cause havoc among a good many existing operators. If that was not enough to cause a bumpy ride for deregulation, the industry was further affected by major oil shocks, the impact of the 1981 air traffic controllers strike and the subsequent sacking of more than 11,000 operators, which effectively reduced the capacity of the air traffic system by about 50 per cent, and the grounding of some DC10 aircraft in the US airline fleet.

Clearly, even the strongest critics of deregulation would have to concede that much of the instability in the US aviation industry has been due in part, perhaps in very large part, to factors other than deregulation. I think that the more relevant standard of comparison, or locus of comparison, with Australia is not so much the United States but Canada. Economic deregulation of the aviation industry in that country occurred at a time when, like in Australia, existing operators were in a strong position, interest rates were high, there was no reservoir of unemployed skilled aviation workers and few used aircraft were available at low prices because so many had been absorbed by the US market.

There are many other points that I could make about the United States experience, including, in particular, the safety experience in the two countries. I make no apology for the emphasis which we are continuing to place on safety regulation. Whether it needs to be exactly the present safety regime as it affects general aviation, the kind of thing which Senator MacGibbon and others have talked about, is something that we can argue out in the specific context of the various legislative and regulatory reviews that I foreshadowed in the statement. I think that it is fair enough to point to the fact that, when one looks at the statistics, the safety experience in the United States has, as I think Senator Sanders pointed out, not been, in fact, anything like as bad as has been alleged. Certainly, there was an acknowledged shortage of experienced surveillance regulators at a time when massive demands were placed upon those limited resources by the influx of new operators. That is something on which we have taken note of the United States experience. I have made a specific commitment on behalf of the Government to ensure that there are ample resources available to meet any changes that might arise in that respect in the Australian environment.

Let me turn to the specifics of the Opposition's amendment to the motion because I think it is important to point out that a number of the criticisms that are contained in the amendment are misconceived. (Quorum formed) Turning to the terms of this rather churlish Opposition amendment to the motion with which the Opposition agrees, let me deal successively and quickly with the points that are made in it. The preamble of the amendment reads:
. . . notes the Government's de facto recognition to privatize Australian Airlines, which is the inevitable and proper consequence of the deregulation of the airline industry;

Let me say, as I said at some length in response to Senator Alston on 9 October in this place, that privatisation of Australian Airlines is neither the inevitable nor necessarily the proper consequence of the deregulation decision. It is important that measures be taken to increase the efficiency of Australian Airlines so that it will be strong and viable in a deregulated environment, and we have taken and announced a series of such measures.
