It is also, of course, necessarily the case that there must be some strengthening of the capital base of Australian Airlines so that it will be able to acquire the fleets necessary to compete effectively in the future. But it is absolutely begging the question to make the assumption, as the terms of this motion do, that that capital base can be provided only through the mechanism of privatisation and equity raising in the private market. That does not necessarily follow at all: it is a matter for judgment, debate, argument and careful analysis of the available data. That is what we will be doing before we make any conclusion on this matter. It is quite misconceived to take the position that this text does.

The amendment goes on to talk about the time lost since the first day that could have seen the ticking of the clock on the three years notice for the end of the agreement; that is, January this year. I simply make the point in this respect that the May report of the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation on which we have premised all our actions on this matter was delivered to the Government only in January this year. We immediately released it for public comment and response. We have proceeded with all deliberate speed throughout this year to formulate a policy which does not pick up only one of the May report options but at the same time deals comprehensively with a whole range of related issues-all the issues: safety, competition policy, foreign investment rules and the future of Australian Airlines. This is obviously a complex policy-making task which this Government has sought to put in place with a great deal of dispatch.

The time that has been lost by this Government in responding to the manifest inadequacies of the two-airline agreement is to be compared with the 27 years of wasted opportunity of our Tory predecessors. From 1952 to 1972 the Tories had 20 years to allow the two-airline agreement to achieve its basic objectives and then to be recognised as the outdated and unnecessary set of constrictions that it was. From 1976 to 1983 there was another seven years of wasted opportunity. For anyone on the other side to come out with this extraordinary cheek of saying that there has been a loss of time or an inadequacy of quick response by this Government is really the usual kind of breathtaking chutzpah that we associate with some of the more outrageous performers on the Opposition front benches.

The amendment also refers to inaction in not preventing the removal of competitors in the airline industry. That simply begs the question of what the response of the Trade Practices Commission will prove to be in relation to the East-West Airlines Ltd acquisition by Ansett Airlines of Australia. It also totally ignores the extent to which a great number of small and regional airlines were gobbled up during the period of operation of the two-airline agreement before this Government chose to act to get rid of it.

In sub-paragraph (c) the Opposition amendment talks about the way in which we are acting now to incorporate the previous Trans Australia Airlines and in doing so are acting contrary to a course which we adopted when we first came into government. I say simply in this respect, as I have said before, that unlike the Bourbons opposite who learn nothing and forget nothing we are able and willing to change our minds if persuaded by force of argument. We have looked at the argument, we have responded to the issues as they have evolved, we have responded to new data, new information and compelling argument, and we have changed our minds. I make no apology for that. It is something I commend to the Opposition to do from time to time in relation to some of the more lunatic policies that it constantly espouses.

There is a reference in sub-paragraph (d) to the absence of informal measures being taken to facilitate deregulation between now and 1990. That simply reflects the ignorance of whoever it was that penned this amendment because, under the terms of the two-airline agreement-which cannot be terminated, amended or altered before 1990 without agreement of all three parties-so long as that agreement prevails, as it will until 1990, there is no way that there can be any informal lesser measures chosen to facilitate, as is suggested in the amendment, the deregulatory processes. One cannot go half way. One cannot be half pregnant when it comes to terminating the two-airline agreement as this sub-paragraph suggests. It is all or nothing. We have taken the decision to make it all.

There is reference in sub-paragraph (e) to the failure to provide the necessary infrastructure at Kingsford-Smith Airport in particular and airports in general. We have recognised the problems with potential and actual congestion that arise at Kingsford-Smith Airport at the moment. To ease the congestion my Department has already introduced air traffic arrangements which involve a flow control system, changes to the use of runways and operational procedures to increase the hourly movement rate, and we have moved to construct additional taxiways. We have, moreover, taken the basic remedial step that our predecessors could never get around to: we have chosen the site for a second Sydney airport and we have begun the process of land acquisition that is necessary for that to go ahead.

There is a reference in sub-paragraph (f) to not completely deregulating domestic and international air freight carried by Australian airlines. Again, that shows a grotesque failure to understand what has been going on. In 1981 domestic freight was deregulated. In fact, the 1981 airlines agreement does not refer to freight because it was in 1981 that domestic freight carriage was deregulated in this country. So much for that part of the paragraph. So far as international freight carriage is concerned, I have announced-I am not sure that anyone has even noticed this part of that very detailed statement on 7 October-a major liberalisation of the rules governing international air freight charters which should mean that there is no longer any effective restriction at all on the capacity of Australian exporters to get their products out of the country, and importers to get them in for that matter, by air freight charters. It is an extensive liberalisation. It is significant. It has been long fought for and long argued by business. There it is. The Opposition cannot even read the text of the statement and the accompanying documentation sufficiently to appreciate that.

The final point made in the amendment refers to the creating of unnecessary uncertainty among Australian Airlines employees as to their future. All I can say is that I have been discussing these issues with Australian Airlines employees and with the unions generally in the aviation industry and that is not a concern that they have expressed to me. They are only too happy about this Government's commitment-the very firm commitment which I articulated in the 7 October statement-to the future of a strong and viable Australian Airlines which we are sure will not only survive in a deregulated environment but be a very powerful and effective competitor in the public interest as well.

I thank the Senate for its support, albeit a little half-hearted in some places, for the basic text of the motion. I do not congratulate the authors of the amendment for this shoddy, patchwork job of half truths, untruths and rhetorical excesses that they have put together. Accordingly, I urge the Senate to reject the amendment and to vote for the basic motion, which has apparently received the unanimous support of this chamber, for which I am duly grateful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1987. This legislation is an attempt to address what might be called insolvency fraud by extending the investigatory powers of bankruptcy trustees. It introduces measures to give debtors advice, counselling and alternatives to bankruptcy. The most important aspect of the Bill is the recognition of insolvency fraud of the sort commented upon by Mr Costigan in his Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-cases which involved sophisticated and complex commercial structures of companies and trusts being used by bankrupts to defeat the claims of their creditors, the bankrupts being protected from the claims of the creditors but secreted property being beyond the reach of the trustees in bankruptcy. The Bill also deals with a number of matters raised by the Australian Law Reform Commission's recently released discussion paper `General Insolvency Inquiry', and in general terms the Bill is in keeping with that paper.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments in the Bill fall into five main categories: firstly, the introduction of a pre-bankruptcy moratorium to enable debtors to consider possible alternative arrangements with creditors; secondly, changes designed to enhance the investigatory powers of the trustee and to enable the trustee to recoup from companies, partnership and trusts, assets which a bankrupt has acquired by personal effort. The Bill introduces concepts of `associated entities' and `examinable affairs' and enables a court to make orders about property of entities controlled by a bankrupt. Thirdly, the Bill seeks to reform part X of the Act to ensure that creditors are provided with full and timely information about a debtor's affairs; fourthly, it seeks to improve the administrative controls over private sector registered trustees, and controls by creditors over those trustees; and, finally, it contains other amendments which are designed to improve the effectiveness of the Act.

It is recognised that the majority of people becoming bankrupt each year are consumer bankrupts who, in most cases, become bankrupt through poor judgment or sometimes misfortune. But there are, of course, other bankruptcies in this country as a result of the mismanagement by this Government of the nation's economy. It is clear that this Government's economic policies are a major contributory factor, with consumer debt running at a record $23,000m and individual savings at their lowest level since the 1982 recession-a situation described by Senator Walsh as a `national malaise' that could seriously affect the economy.

According to the Law Reform Commission in its discussion paper on insolvency, insolvency is a valuable indicator of trends in the economic system and one of the reasons is that people seek credit to maintain their standard of living. The Hawke-Keating economic policies have lowered the living standards of all Australians and it is hardly surprising that bankruptcies have increased so dramatically as people have attempted to maintain their living standards. Bankruptcies for the year ended 30 June 1987 have risen to 7,495, compared with 5,539 for the year ended 30 June 1986-a massive 35.3 per cent increase. The Government should be endeavouring to address the root causes of this problem. If this Government continues to ignore the warning signs, the rate of increase in bankruptcies will accelerate like the national debt, despite the alternatives to bankruptcy outlined in this Bill. Provision is now made for the introduction of a limited pre-bankruptcy moratorium to enable debtors to consider possible alternatives to bankruptcy.

Turning to specific issues in the Bill, I would like to deal firstly with insolvency fraud. The Costigan Royal Commission referred to the activities of a person called Lockyer who spent 23 years as a bankrupt. He used his bankruptcy as a shield against his creditors and was estimated by his wife to be worth some $5m, notwithstanding that he was a bankrupt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Together with his wife.

—I am sorry, he and his wife were worth $5m. The Australian Law Reform Commission states that there is clear evidence that in a number of cases the spirit of part X has been deliberately abused by a variety of devices, including misleading information, insufficient notice of meetings, convening meetings in obscure places, stacking meetings or conducting meetings without an impartial chairman. A range of measures has been introduced to lift the corporate veil and the Opposition supported similar procedures in the Crimes Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The pre-bankruptcy moratorium gives debtors seven days to consider the alternatives to bankruptcy. The Registrar is to direct the debtor to sources of guidance and advice, although no additional resources have been made available by the Government for this purpose. I must say that on the rare occasions I was involved in bankruptcy proceedings when I was practising in my profession I had some difficulties because of the lack of information available to debtors as to their bankruptcy alternatives. I think making available this sort of guidance and advice in simple, understandable language is an excellent reform. The simple alternatives could be explained in understandable language to people who are in what might be expected to be the `normal' form of bankruptcy. For example, a business person who is unable to pay his debts but who may, in due course, be able to trade his way out of bankruptcy ought to take a particular course. By comparison, someone who has lost everything may be able to get back on his feet only by taking an alternative course.

The Australian Law Reform Commission says that some debtors have become bankrupt unnecessarily-that is, that part X may have been more appropriate. It says that there is no public counselling or advisory service and proposes that such a service be funded by Commonwealth legal aid agencies. The reforms of part X include, firstly, a requirement that a statement of affairs be prepared prior to the debtor authorising the calling of a meeting; secondly, a requirement that the statement be provided to creditors when they are notified of the meeting; thirdly, a requirement that the trustee prepare a report for creditors to assist the meetings of creditors; fourthly, a provision whereby the meetings that do not fulfil certain criteria are invalidated; fifthly, a provision for the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy to have the right to apply to set aside part X deeds, et cetera; sixthly, a requirement that the examination of trustees be by a registrar, not a court; seventhly, a provision that a creditor or his spouse is not entitled to vote at a creditor's meeting; and, eighthly, a provision for the giving of proxies, which is referred to in the Australian Law Reform Commission paper.

There are some difficulties with the requirement that a statement of affairs be prepared and provided to creditors prior to the meeting. I can well understand that, because the statement of affairs is frequently very difficult to prepare. Frankly, by that stage many of the bankrupts do not know to whom they owe money as they owe money in so many areas. They do not know the amount they might owe. They have been going from pillar to post trying to run a cash economy or a cash system of payments. At the same time, they have been trying to get funds into their bank. They believe that some cheques they have made out have been met, whereas subsequently they turn out to have bounced. There are all sorts of problems in practice in trying to prepare a statement of affairs.

The Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia is of the view that the delay caused by the preparation of a statement of affairs is such that it will disadvantage the creditors. As I said, I have had some small experience in this area, and that was what I found. On the other hand, the Australian Law Reform Commission paper supports the requirement of the Bill. All I can say is that we do not oppose the provision in the Bill, but we shall be taking advice from practitioners in the area as to how it works in practice. We will keep a general watch on this aspect of the proposed change, with a view to dealing with it when we are in government, in accordance with what the result should be.

There are a number of other minor matters, including maintenance agreements, a spouse's claim to rank with other unsecured creditors, and the allowing of a bankrupt to keep a vehicle to the value of $2,500. We will be fascinated to know what the Government will do in the case of someone who owns a Mercedes and who says that its value is $2,500. No doubt some people will try to do that. Another minor matter is the fact that statements of affairs are to be changed administratively. The amendments in clause 98 require an owner of premises to allow reasonable use of the facilities to persons holding a warrant. Again, the Opposition has difficulty with this matter. The provisions are similar to those in the fringe benefits tax proposal and other recent tax legislation. The Opposition has previously emphasised its objection to such wide powers. We believe that when these facilities are required to be provided there ought to be some form of compensation to the person who has to provide the facilities. Nevertheless, it is not a matter that we will take to the barricades.

Finally, I mention that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has raised reservations with respect to clauses 35 and 36, which amend the powers of the Official Receiver. But the Scrutiny of Bills Committee recognised that the new provisions do not differ from those contained in section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act. As I said, the Opposition welcomes the Bill. We will not oppose it. We shall be interested to see how it works in practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1987. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) noted in his second reading speech, the Bill marks a major turning point in the administration of bankruptcy law in this country. It is a process which is very slow-in fact, much slower than we would have hoped at this stage. Essentially, the Bill arises from royal commissioner Costigan's findings that the bankruptcy laws were being abused by fraudulently motivated insolvency claims. There is no doubt that modern bankruptcy law, in itself, is quite inadequate in attacking insolvency fraud, while also providing protection for innocent people whose bankruptcies have arisen from misfortune. In particular, we have seen in recent times an increasing number of abuses of insolvency law. There are some quite infamous cases of bankruptcy's being used as a deliberate device to defeat the claims of creditors by concealing property in complex trust or corporate structure arrangements, thereby putting it beyond the reach of the trustee in bankruptcy.

SPEECH.PARA: To help overcome these problems, some of which have been addressed by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 2) 1986, the amendments in this Bill cover five main areas. The first is the introduction of a pre-bankruptcy moratorium to enable debtors to consider possible alternative arrangements with their creditors. This is obviously a desirable move. At the end of the day, those who are owed money would obviously prefer to be able to get as much back as possible. This can often be done by keeping the bankrupt in a trading situation. Hence, an earlier movement would be of much more interest to people if it were possible for the company, or the individual, to trade its way out of difficulties.

Under the new division 2a of part IV, a debtor will be able to present to the Registrar in Bankruptcy a declaration of intent to present a debtor's petition. Once this is accepted by the Registrar, the debtor will be able to invoke a limited stay upon certain debt recovery processes for a maximum period of seven days. The Registrar will be obliged to direct the debtor's attention to the sources of advice and guidance about his financial affairs and to the proceedings under the Bankruptcy Act dealing with insolvency. This process will almost certainly prove to be more constructive and co-operative than past practice has been.

The second major change is designed to improve the investigatory powers of bankruptcy trustees and to enable asset recoupment from corporations, partnerships and trusts, which a bankrupt has used to conceal property, the use and enjoyment of which is reserved to the bankrupt, but which has the appearance of being owned by a company or a trust. One can recall many outrageous examples, as Senator Lewis has already done with regard to one case. I can think of another case in my State whereby a technical bankrupt not only continued to enjoy the use of substantial assets but also ended up qualifying for legal aid.

In this context, the powers of the trustee in bankruptcy to realise a debtor's property for distribution among creditors and to protect the public interest by investigating the bankrupt's conduct with a view to upholding standards of commercial morality have not kept pace with modern corporate reality. Increasingly, some debtors have developed a maze of family trusts and companies which gives the impression that they are totally without assets. As I said before, they continue to enjoy the use of these secreted assets and properties which have the guise of being owned elsewhere. Practices, such as remuneration skimming, which put assets of companies and trusts associated with a debtor beyond the trustee or creditors fall within this category. Constraints on the property which can be realised by the trustee compound this problem.

The Bill has extended the trustee's powers to investigate the bankrupt's financial affairs and enable the trustee to recoup from companies, trusts, partnerships and other devices assets which have been acquired by the personal efforts of the bankrupt. The introduction of related concepts of associated entities and examinable affairs and the new division 4a of part VI will enable the court to make orders in relation to the property of entities controlled by a bankrupt. Associated entities will now include those which the bankrupt is able to influence by virtue of close business or family relationships. Examinable affairs which the trustee will be able to investigate will include the financial affairs of an entity associated with a bankrupt to the extent that those financial affairs are relevant to the bankrupt's financial affairs. This extension of powers will no doubt do much to remedy the deficiencies in the existing laws.

The third major change is to part X of the Act to ensure that creditors are provided with full and timely information about debtors' affairs. Again, some flaws in the existing legislation have been exploited by unscrupulous trustees and solicitors in order to defraud creditors. The three major problems concern insufficient information; the omission of provisions which ensure that previous dealings between a debtor, creditors and the trustee are disclosed; and inadequate supervision of part X arrangements. All three of these problems are addressed in the Bill. It seems probable-we certainly hope it is true-that the abuse of proceedings under part X will be minimised as a result of this movement.

The final two areas affected by the Bill are improvements in the administrative controls over private sector registered trustees and controls by creditors over trustees and other amendments. Generally speaking, this Bill represents some much needed and long overdue improvements in bankruptcy law. However, the Government hopefully will not be resting on its laurels upon the passage of this particular piece of legislation by the Senate today or early tomorrow at the latest. Discussion paper No. 32 of the Australian Law Reform Commission was put down in August this year. It outlines a whole range of suggested reforms. If one took to heart the Commission's discussion paper relating to the general insolvency inquiry reference, then one would see some massive pieces of legislation coming into this chamber in the not too distant future. However, if the introduction of those pieces of legislation is as tardy as this legislation was, I suppose they will be introduced some time in the next Parliament.

I draw attention to an item which Senator Haines has raised on innumerable occasions; that is, the problems confronting primary industry and people who are classified as unsecured creditors. For example, when a winery or a cannery goes into liquidation, the difficulties of small creditors are in conflict with large corporate debtors. The discussion paper covers a whole range of areas and the proposals seem to be not only workable but also will probably shift the balance towards unsecured creditors. It seems very odd that the people who have provided the grapes or the produce are at the very end of the line when it comes to an exercise in bankruptcy, whereas trading their way out of operations often means that they will be using the very products which have been provided by the unsecured creditors.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which is due to report tomorrow, raised a number of queries to clause 35, which deals with the powers of officials and commissions, clause 36, which deals with the powers of officials, and clauses 51(2) and 91(2), which deal with the retrospectivity of operating clauses. As is usual with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the initial report would then give the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) the opportunity to respond. Since the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has not had a chance to bring down its report-I understand it will be coming out tomorrow-the response by the Minister will not be available to senators and that is rather unfortunate. I had assumed that this Bill would have come on tomorrow, but for other reasons it has been reshuffled into this time slot, hence I am somewhat at a disadvantage. I do not want to take up the time of the Senate by going through the whole report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I think it has made its point very firmly in its preliminary report.

The Australian Democrats are inclined to support some of the items that are included in this report. However, I am at a disadvantage because I have not heard the Minister's response and the Minister will not be making his response until the end of the second reading debate which is very close to the committee stage. I do not know whether it is possible, but I think it would be useful to postpone the committee stage until tomorrow. If the Minister is indicating that he does not want to do that, it may very well be that we will have a committee debate that goes after 6.30 p.m., which means that the Bill will be debated tomorrow. I hope that the Minister will not incorporate his response. If the Minister can briefly explain his response in the second reading debate it may very well be that we can move rapidly through the committee stage today, but at the moment I am inclined not to think so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill. I am grateful to my colleague Senator Lewis for the outline that he has given to the major amendments proposed and the matters that I think do need serious addressing. Essentially this needs to be looked at in two ways. Bankruptcy legislation has been notorious for its complexity. Those of us who have had anything to do with it would agree that the legislation and the practice were both replete with arcane legalisms and it was very difficult to ever get a result that was satisfactory. But that was prior to the days when it became relatively easy for someone to go in and out of bankruptcy. As a result of that gradual wearing down of the real burden, despite the pettifogging that still went on, incentives were created for people to abuse the system. As a result this amendment is designed to cope with what have been a number of serious instances of fraud. I think it quite properly does deal with some of the ways in which people have used and abused this legislation for the benefit of themselves and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly I think it is desirable that there be facilities for people to file for voluntary bankruptcy. I think debtor petitions are a very desirable option that should be available, but it is equally desirable that there should be a cooling off period, that people should be able to get advice and counselling and should be able to appreciate what is involved not only in becoming bankrupt but in subsequently trying to be released from bankruptcy. There is certainly a lesser social stigma attached to it than there was, but it does create impediments for those who want to resume life as company directors and play an active part in the business community.

One can only applaud the way in which the Bill makes it a lot easier for people who are genuinely wanting to file for bankruptcy to address the implications but, at the same time, it deals with those who have deliberately abused the system. The example of Mr Lockyer is dealt with in the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I think it is probably a classic example. But there are a number of others, including some people in very high places, who have taken the opportunity of an impending judgment against them to transfer their assets to their spouses, and also to relatives and friends. That sort of thing can be done with relative impunity as long as one has sufficient foresight. I think it is one aspect of the law that does infuriate not only creditors but also the community at large if they see that it is relatively easy for someone with good legal advice to ensure that prior to the entry of judgment that one can simply transfer one's assets to others.

Insolvency fraud is a function not just of the occasional criminal but, I think in some instances, has almost become an additional mechanism for laundering funds and for organised criminals to rearrange their affairs in a way that obviously defeats their creditors. The reform of part X is designed to ensure that creditors will have the opportunity to be fully aware of the size and extent of the potential bankrupt's estate and to have those necessary details before them before they can make an informed decision. Whilst I note that the insolvency practitioners have some real reservations about the effectiveness of the requirement for notice, I must say I find it difficult to comprehend the logic of their argument. It would seem to me that although, no doubt, there have been a minority who will abuse the process, at the end of the day it is much more desirable to go into such a conference for a composition of creditors armed with at least some information, rather than simply having to attend and take the word of the bankrupt for his state of insolvency.

The reforms of part X which require notices and advanced statements and generally facilitate the ability of the registrar to examine the trustee are desirable changes. Limitations on the role that can be played by spouses and those steps that will ensure that debtors and their creditors are at arm's length are very desirable. Certainly, there have been abuses in the area of maintenance agreements. Transfers to spouses have been one obvious area of abuse and the provision that, henceforth, spouses' claims will not rank above those of ordinary creditors, is justified in the circumstances, although there may be situations in which a spouse has genuinely lent funds to enable a person in financial difficulties to trade out. By and large, that has not been an arm's length relationship and spouses will have to take their chances.

While I welcome the thrust of this Bill and acknowledge the desirability of cleaning up its provisions, it is worth noting, when talking about bankruptcies, that we are operating at record levels. In the nine months to 31 March this year, the total number of bankruptcies was 5,478-up by 1,579 over the corresponding nine-month period. The figure for the year ending 30 June would normally have been available by now, and the uncharitable interpretation would be that they have been deliberately withheld so as not to compromise the inquiry into consumer debt which seems to have caught the fancy of several Ministers, including Mr Staples, who wants to make a bit of a name for himself. It is not hard to understand why there has been an increase in consumer debt and a record number of bankruptcies. If we were to project those figures through on a 12-month basis, we would be looking at about 8,000 bankruptcies in the last financial year. That is a sad reflection on the state of the economy.

It could be the case-I suspect that there are a number in this situation-that there are people who would normally have been able to survive in the economic climate but, because of reductions in real wages, tightening in the economy and creditors who have taken a harder line, have not been able to trade out of their predicament. That is a reflection on the way in which the Government has handled the economy. In the 4 1/2 years that it has had to create a more propitious commercial climate, the end result is a record number of bankruptcies. That is open to the interpretation that we would not have such record numbers were it not for the fact that people have been forced to get into debt and go beyond their means and have then found that bankruptcy is the most attractive way out.

I do not suppose that Senator Tate will suggest, and I am not suggesting, that the majority of the total number, or even the majority of the increase, of bankrupts are those who are abusing the system or who are part of the abuse process that the Bill attempts to remedy. The vast majority of those who go bankrupt do so because they bite off more than they can chew. Usually, they are small business people who do not know the way in which the system operates, and at the end of the day they are the people who are faced with record high interest rates, and who find life difficult, with high inflation, award wage increases that they have to bear and all sorts of economic constraints which operate on them in an economic environment that is not growing. They find that they simply do not have the opportunity to trade out of their problems. That is an indictment, and it is something that we should not forget when we are discussing bankruptcies. It would be presenting an unbalanced picture if we were simply to look at the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill in the context of a few tidying up amendments without also looking at the gross number of persons who have found it necessary to go into voluntary or involuntary bankruptcy. With those remarks, I join in the support for the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate. We regard this legislation as being vital. It is somewhat delayed, given the intervention of the election, and I am appreciative of those honourable senators who have shown an awareness of the need to get this legislation on the statute books and operational as soon as possible. In particular, I think that the general public is concerned about the matters that were revealed by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, such as bankrupts using a plethora of family trusts and companies, and so organising their affairs that they are apparently without any assets but are still enjoying the use of those properties and assets because they are under the guise of being owned by some company or trust. People want to see that attacked, and this legislation does that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill does some other equally important things. Before I remark on those, I simply put on the record that, while the number of bankruptcies has increased in the way that has been indicated, the statistics show that the rate of business bankruptcies has been relatively stable in the years since the Hawke Government came into power. The Government believes that the relative stability in relation to business bankruptcies shows that its economic policies are working. The overall increase in bankruptcies is attributable to the substantial increase in non-business bankruptcies, and that is a matter of great concern to us. The Government has agreed, and Mr Staples is making the running on this, to convene a meeting under the auspices of the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council to examine certain aspects of consumer credit marketing and credit assessment techniques used by financiers. That will be an important meeting. In addition, some $190,000 was provided in the Budget to enable additional consumer education on financial matters to be undertaken. I could elaborate on that, but I do not have enough time to do so at this stage.
I turn now to what Mr Tuckey said, interestingly enough, in his remarks in the House of Representatives on 16 April 1985. He asked the Attorney-General:

. . . in framing future legislation, to think to some extent on what the Ombudsman has suggested; that is, that there is room for a cooling-off period, in the same way that, in buying encyclopaedias, a person can change his mind in a day or so.

Part of this legislation provides for that cooling off period, which we believe will, on occasion, enable those who could perhaps continue to trade to do so, and will certainly allow some time for advice to be sought from financial consultants, debt counsellors and so on. This may have an impact on the number of persons who would otherwise go in automatically and become bankrupt.

The resources for providing information for debtors in bankruptcy and the alternatives is something which needs to be addressed, and I know that Senator Lewis made some point of this. During 1986-87, the Government provided funds for preparation of a script for an information video on bankruptcy and its alternatives. The first draft of the script has been prepared by Film Australia and is now being revised. We hope that the video will be produced this financial year and made available not only in bankruptcy offices but in centres such as legal aid offices and places where debt counselling occurs, in order to provide those who might otherwise rush into the bankruptcy situation with some knowledge of the various alternatives in a convenient and attractive video.

My main task is to reply to Senator Macklin who raised the question of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report-an alert digest as it is called. I wrote to the Chairman of that Committee some days ago and admittedly my reply is not available generally to honourable senators at this stage. However, the four clauses to which the Committee drew the Senate's attention fell into two categories. Clauses 35 and 36 were cited by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee:
on the ground that they confer on officials powers of uncertain breadth and without adequate safeguards.
In my reply I pointed out:
Both trustees and Official Receivers are subject to very rigorous scrutiny, both judicial and official, and that degree of scrutiny will be enhanced by the Bill.
After a page or two of argument verifying that point, I concluded:

Accordingly it is my view that there is a more than adequate level of scrutiny over the actions of trustees and Official Receivers when exercising their existing powers and the new powers to be conferred upon them by the Bill.

It is in relation to clauses 51 and 91 that the most concern and genuine misgivings may be felt. Clause 51, in my opinion, confers upon the court a new power to deal with existing matters. This should be contrasted with retrospectivity where the law is expressed to operate from a past date. Professor Pearce states in Statutory Interpretation in Australia:

(few) Acts do not interfere with some existing right. The usual intention of a legislature is to make some change in an existing course of conduct. It is, therefore, appropriate to talk in terms of retrospectivity only where an Act affects rights by changing them with effect prior to the commencement of the amending Act.

In those terms clause 51 is not retrospective. As far as clause 91 is concerned, I believe that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has based its remarks on an incorrect interpretation of that provision. Sub-clause 91 (2) is a clarifying provision. The correct interpretation of it is that the conduct which will constitute the offence must occur after the commencement of the provision. However, the new offence will apply even if the meeting was called pursuant to a section 188 authority signed before commencement. This is the effect of the application provision in sub-clause 91 (2).

I believe that we are not confronted by true retrospectivity. I believe that the breadth of the powers given to official receivers and trustees is subject to sufficiently rigorous scrutiny, both judicially and officially, to enable the legitimate misgivings and fears raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to be set at rest. I anticipate that that will be confirmed at the meeting of the Committee to be held tomorrow. I believe that I have answered those matters which have been raised. In view of the need to process this legislation as rapidly as possible, I conclude the second reading debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for his response at the end of the second reading debate to the items raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I wish to refer to one such item; that is, clause 91 (2). Clause 91 (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not, in connection with giving to the chairman of a meeting of creditors held under an authority under section 188 particulars of a debt, knowingly make a statement that is false or misleading in a material particular.
There is provision for a penalty of $1,000 or six months imprisonment. Clause 91 (2) states:
The section inserted in the Principal Act by subsection (1) applies in relation to an authority under section 188 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966, whenever signed.

Quite frankly, I am not interested in Lord Denham's comments about a statute. I am not saying that the Act will be retrospective; what I am interested in is whether this clause is retrospective. I thought that is what the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was interested in too. Is it not the case that if, at a meeting held before the Act is signed and where a bankruptcy matter is in process, a false and misleading statement is made in regard to that action, a penalty will now apply as a result of clause 91 (2)? If that is not the case, obviously the provision is not retrospective. But, if that is the case, the provision obviously is retrospective.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that the very best advice that I have obtained from the Attorney-General's Department and from the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy, who is with me in the chamber, is that clause 91 (2) is a clarifying provision. The correct interpretation of it is that the conduct which will constitute the offence-Senator Macklin has mentioned the penalty-must occur after the commencement of the provision. However, the new offence will apply even if the meeting was called pursuant to a section 188 authority signed before commencement. That is the only point to be made. The actual conduct which can attract a penalty must occur after the commencement of this provision.

—As we are talking of clarifying things, I would like to get this matter quite clear. If a meeting, an action or whatever has started and is in process now and continues past the proclamation date of this piece of legislation, and a false and misleading statement is knowingly made today, will no action be taken? If such a statement is knowingly made after the proclamation, will action be taken under the proposed new section 263c?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is precisely that. If such a statement were made today it would not attract a penalty, even if it was knowingly false.
